story:
Who We Are

I Pour Life offers a hand up to end poverty both locally and globally, one individual, one family, one community at a time. 

We believe in developing the most critical individuals in the areas we serve, including at-risk and homeless youth and women with HIV and leprosy. We focus on developing individuals' unique talents and skills and teaching them how to use those skills for long-term self-sufficiency and personal sustainability.

We are hosting a fake marathon on April 1 to raise awareness for our organization and to give you the opportunity to say you ran a marathon, without actually having to do any running! 

What better day to host a fake marathon than April Fool's Day?! Put on your best running gear, and get bragging rights while giving a hand up to end poverty. Just make sure to contribute to our social media campaign using #RaiseDontRun, #NoRunRun, and #IPourLife.

The Plan

If you want to be part of the best April Fool's Day ever and support our cause, join us for the greatest marathon you will NEVER run!

Serious props to you if you can run 26.2 miles in a day, the rest of us will settle for bragging rights and one of those nifty marathon stickers for our windshields! 

Our Goal:  to raise funds and awareness for our organization

What you can do: Register for the No Run Run, sport your racing gear on April 1st, and take pictures to show your friends how you are helping to end poverty! Follow our social media campaign for tips on how to stage the best fake marathon pics, and other helpful information!

Between now and April 1st, help us raise awareness by sharing posts or creating your own. Make sure to tag your posts with #RaiseDontRun, #NoRunRun, and #IPourLife!

What We Need & What You Get

Not only will this campaign raise awareness about our organization and our cause, it will raise funds essential to continuing our impact both locally and globally. 

After covering the cost of your awesome racing gear, 100% of the funds from this campaign will be used to change the life of an individual, their family, and community. You get all the same racing gear as if you were running an actual marathon, but the biggest perk is you don't actually have to do any running--unless you want to! Get your friends involved and sign up as a team for the No Run Run to receive limited edition sweatbands.
This year's No Run Run merchandise includes:  No Run Run t-shirt (unisex sizes, and extra comfortable--just don't forget to email us your size!), a race bracelet, race bib--also known as nifty marathon number, a marathon sticker, a water bottle, and a sweat band. Make sure to check out all of the registration options and select which works best for you (and includes the best merch)!
Since this is our first annual No Run Run, we are conducting an "all or nothing" campaign, which is why it is essential for you to get involved! Without enough supporters this fake race can't happen--the more runners, the more awareness, the more support provided to people in need.
You will get bragging rights to say you participated in the first annual No Run Run for I Pour Life, some pretty neat merchandise, and the irreplaceable feeling that comes from giving back to those in need!

The Impact

While racing gear is cool, and funding is essential, raising awareness about our efforts is what will keep our organization running in the end--pun intended.

Globally over 1 billion people live on a devastating income — making less than $1.25
a day. Most of the problems threatening families in the developing world are
a direct result of this poverty. We believe in dropping differences to make a difference by offering a hand up to end poverty. Through your help, our efforts are impacting impoverished communities, both locally and globally.

In Ethiopia, we run a women's empowerment program called 10x10 which teaches essential business and life skills to women affected by leprosy and HIV/AIDS. These women are living with their families in a community built on top of a trash dump in Korah, Ethiopia, but through our program, many have gone from making $0.30 a day to $7-$10 per day!

In El Salvador, we are bridging the gap between churches and communities through our gang-prevention program called LiveGold. Children as young as 11 years old are often recruited by gangs, but by offering these kids another option, LiveGold is strengthening families and communities. In 2016 we plan to launch the same program in Honduras and continue impacting South America!

Locally, we work with at-risk and homeless youth through our LifeStrengths development system. We discovered many youth living government-assisted lifestyles have been socially isolated, but through LifeStrengths, these individuals are developing skills to become self-sufficient. We pair individuals with a LifeCoach so they can work together, developing strength in the areas of education, employment, and personal development!

Risks & Challenges

As a growing organization, we are still working to develop awareness about our efforts and our initiatives. While each of our programs has achieved success in the areas we serve, in 2016, we want to touch as many lives as possible. Obviously, that requires funding and awareness, which wouldn't happen without people like you!

We have an amazing team, and we're not just saying that because we know they're going to read this... But one thing we cannot do without your help is spread the word about our efforts. We want people like you to not only get involved, but stay involved, by spreading awareness and supporting our efforts, so we can continue impacting global poverty and doing fun things like faking a marathon along the way.

We will never agree on everything, but what we can agree on is dropping differences to make a difference and offering a hand up to end poverty, one individual, one family, one community at a time! How's that for a tag line?

Other Ways You Can Help

Even if you can't financially contribute, you have a specific set of skills we need! Use social media to spread the word using the hashtags #RaiseDontRun #NoRunRun and #IPourLife!

Tell all of your friends about the No Run Run campaign! Call them, text them, send snail mail, a smoke signal, or a carrier pigeon - whatever works!

Get ready for the best fake marathon you'll never run!

Serious props to you if you can run 26.2 miles in a day, the rest of us will settle for bragging rights and one of those nifty marathon stickers for our windshields! 
Our Goal:  to raise funds and awareness for our organization
What you can do: Register for the No Run Run, sport your racing gear on April 1st, and take pictures to show your friends how you are helping to end poverty! Follow our social media campaign for tips on how to stage the best fake marathon pics, and other helpful information!
Between now and April 1st, help us raise awareness by sharing posts or creating your own. Make sure to tag your posts with #RaiseDontRun, #NoRunRun, and #IPourLife!





What We Need & What You Get


Not only will this campaign raise awareness about our organization and our cause, it will raise funds essential to continuing our impact both locally and globally. 
After covering the cost of your awesome racing gear, 100% of the funds from this campaign will be used to change the life of an individual, their family, and community. You get all the same racing gear as if you were running an actual marathon, but the biggest perk is you don't actually have to do any running--unless you want to! Get your friends involved and sign up as a team for the No Run Run to receive limited edition sweatbands.

This year's No Run Run merchandise includes:  No Run Run t-shirt (unisex sizes, and extra comfortable--just don't forget to email us your size!), a race bracelet, race bib--also known as nifty marathon number, a marathon sticker, a water bottle, and a sweat band. Make sure to check out all of the registration options and select which works best for you (and includes the best merch)!

Since this is our first annual No Run Run, we are conducting an "all or nothing" campaign, which is why it is essential for you to get involved! Without enough supporters this fake race can't happen--the more runners, the more awareness, the more support provided to people in need.
You will get bragging rights to say you participated in the first annual No Run Run for I Pour Life, some pretty neat merchandise, and the irreplaceable feeling that comes from giving back to those in need!

The Impact
 While racing gear is cool, and funding is essential, raising awareness about our efforts is what will keep our organization running in the end--pun intended.
Globally over 1 billion people live on a devastating income — making less than $1.25a day. Most of the problems threatening families in the developing world area direct result of this poverty. We believe in dropping differences to make a difference by offering a hand up to end poverty. Through your help, our efforts are impacting impoverished communities, both locally and globally.
In Ethiopia, we run a women's empowerment program called 10x10 which teaches essential business and life skills to women affected by leprosy and HIV/AIDS. These women are living with their families in a community built on top of a trash dump in Korah, Ethiopia, but through our program, many have gone from making $0.30 a day to $7-$10 per day!
In El Salvador, we are bridging the gap between churches and communities through our gang-prevention program called LiveGold. Children as young as 11 years old are often recruited by gangs, but by offering these kids another option, LiveGold is strengthening families and communities. In 2016 we plan to launch the same program in Honduras and continue impacting South America!
Locally, we work with at-risk and homeless youth through our LifeStrengths development system. We discovered many youth living government-assisted lifestyles have been socially isolated, but through LifeStrengths, these individuals are developing skills to become self-sufficient. We pair individuals with a LifeCoach so they can work together, developing strength in the areas of education, employment, and personal development!





Risks & Challenges

As a growing organization, we are still working to develop awareness about our efforts and our initiatives. While each of our programs has achieved success in the areas we serve, in 2016, we want to touch as many lives as possible. Obviously, that requires funding and awareness, which wouldn't happen without people like you!
We have an amazing team, and we're not just saying that because we know they're going to read this... But one thing we cannot do without your help is spread the word about our efforts. We want people like you to not only get involved, but stay involved, by spreading awareness and supporting our efforts, so we can continue impacting global poverty and doing fun things like faking a marathon along the way.
We will never agree on everything, but what we can agree on is dropping differences to make a difference and offering a hand up to end poverty, one individual, one family, one community at a time! How's that for a tag line?




Other Ways You Can Help

Even if you can't financially contribute, you have a specific set of skills we need! Use social media to spread the word using the hashtags #RaiseDontRun #NoRunRun and #IPourLife!
Tell all of your friends about the No Run Run campaign! Call them, text them, send snail mail, a smoke signal, or a carrier pigeon - whatever works!
Get ready for the best fake marathon you'll never run!

story:
Like so many things, it began barbecuing in our backyard. Sitting around the firepit, enjoying the grilled fruits of our labor, and a thought: what if we started a food truck? Perhaps it was because, being late shifters, we found ourselves without any desirable options when we wanted someone else to prepare our dinner, that this thought lingered. It may have been because we regularly spent date nights experimenting in the kitchen, impressing ourselves night after night. Maybe it was because we wanted, and were ready, to do more than just punch a clock. It was quickly clear that this thought was not fleeting. This was a thought that demanded action.


Who We Are And What We Do And Why We Think We Can Pull This Off

Plain and Fancy is a collaboration between Evan Monaghan and Ashleigh Altemann, or Mr. Plain and Ms. Fancy respectively. Evan has nearly ten years experience in the restaurant industry, both front of house, back of house and management.

“I've worked hard making other people's food, but I would much rather work hard to make our food.”

Armed with 5 years experience at an internet marketing startup, and a bachelors degree from the College for Creative Studies, Ashleigh finds Plain and Fancy to be the perfect outlet for her many interests and talents.

“In college I found out I had a knack for food photography, I didn't really know how to cook at the time, but have since found I seem to have a knack for that as well.”

 

So, What is Plain and Fancy?


We are a mobile food establishment. (That's our “fancy” name. You could also call us a “food caboose.” Point is we're a trailer, not a truck). Our goal is pretty simple - good food, good prices, good times. To help us along the way we've got a sturdy flat top, a fantastic fryer, the good ol' grill, and to top it off, the supreme smoker. Hot damn!

Since that barbeque nearly two years ago we have been tinkering, creating recipes, researching, and planning. In early March we purchased the new Plain and Fancy Food Trailer from a nice gentleman in Nashville, Tennessee. And we promptly drove it straight through a snowstorm.

 

Now we just need the finishing touches.

A picture of our beloved trailer as it stands:

 

A little sketch of how we're planning to make this plain old thing a little fancier:



What We Need to Get the Rest of the Way

Getting the old food caboose home is one thing, getting her ready to open is another. That’s why we need your help. Your contribution to this campaign will help us pay for some of the things we need before we can cook a single dish. This includes:

  • A generator
  • Two or three burner gas range and propane tanks
  • LLC Incorporation, business license, health department certifications, etc.
  • Meat-Grinder
  • Slicer
  • General kitchen equipment
  • Paint and other remodeling supplies
  • Opening food costs, Kitchen rental costs and other expenses

 

Those That Give Deserve Also, To Receive!

We are offering gift certificates redeemable at Plain and Fancy once we are rolling!

For contributing at any of our other perk levels, you will receive your very own Plain and Fancy keychain. Not only are these stylish accessories (would you expect anything less from Ms. Fancy?) but they will also unlock Turnkey specials once we open. For contributions of $20, we’ll draw something for you, Anything you want. And if you can’t decide, we’ll surprise you. Contribute $30, and we’ll send you a recipe, straight from the Plain and Fancy development labs so you can whip up fancy foods of your own! At $50 we’ll keep you clean when you’re under pressure with an awesome apron, designed and printed by Mr. Plain and Ms. Fancy. $100 get's you the whole kit and caboodle. Lastly, if you've got 25 friends (or acquaintances, co-workers, family, etc.) and $500, we'll bring the food to your hoppin' party.

 

You Don’t Have to Be Rich to Be Fancy!

What if you want to help but can’t contribute financially? We still need you! Help us with knowledge or tools. Got a good source for cheap restaurant equipment? Tell us where to find it! Know of a location with a lot of hungry people for us to feed? We’ll be there! And most of all, please be sure to tell all of your friends about this campaign and to like us on Facebook.



Thank you so much. With your help we’ll be serving up Oakland County in no time.

story:
Short Summary

On December 22nd, three days before Christmas in the middle of the night our furnace stopped working. We have a home warranty plan, that came with our home purchase that we thought would take care of it, we were wrong. It is now plummeting well below zero around here and still no furnace. We are lucky enough to have friends that have provided us with electric heaters to keep half the house warm. We have moved the three kids in to one room next to ours so we can run a heater in the hallway and keep both rooms warm. We keep the main living room warm and kitchen and have a small heater we move around to spot heat like the bathroom. I can only imagine what our power bill is going to cost us over the next couple of months. Another problem we have around here is our main bathroom. When we bought our home, everything seemed to work fine. Then we tried to bathe the baby and the bathtub wouldn't drain. We called a drain person to come out and we found out the pipes were completely blocked coming from the tub and they would need replaced. The bathroom is completely outdated and needs some work. The tub and toilet is a 1970's burnt orange and the floor below the toilet looks like its slowly sinking. We have gotten by with bathing the kids either at Grandma's or the kitchen sink. We have a shower, but the baby does not like it one bit. Not to mention he has a skin infection, which required he be bathed and scrubbed twice a day.

A little about us

My name is Heidi and my husband is Andy. We have three beautiful children: Blaykli 12, Dexton 5 and Sway 18 months. I have always worked a lot, both before our marriage and during, up until November 1st. I decided then, that I was going to scale back and spend more time with our children. Andy was making good money and enough that would allow me to stay home a little more. Shortly after I gave my notice and my position was replaced, my husband lost his job. Fortunately I worked for family, so they were able to find me things to do to keep us above water for a short period of time. Andy then got a new job November 13th and was working lots of overtime and making more then he was before. We caught up on our bills and was feeling good, then the job ended on December 10th, sooner then we thought. We had saved enough for a small Christmas for the kids and that was about it. Andy is still without work, probably for at least a few more weeks and we need a furnace. Even if he does go back to work sooner or later, we are so far behind on our bills, it will take us a little while to catch up.

What We Need & What You Get

We have a bid for a new furnace and to bring everything up to code, that is not safe in our utility room. It will cost $4062 to replace the furnace and run the proper ventilation fresh air pipes which includes drilling holes through the brick of the house. We have received a bid of $3087 to remodel the bathroom moderatly and reuse some of our current fixtures. The remainder of the money $2851 will pay for any additional costs in case there are problems unseen in the remodel or update. It will also help pay for the power bill that is quickly adding up with the electric heaters. If we do not reach our goal, any money received will be put towards the furnace and remodel. I know its not much, but there are some perks we have set up for the certain donation amounts, I wish we could give something for every donation, I hope a simple thank you is plenty for your kindness..

The Impact

I know I am asking for something personal, when there are so many other causes to contribute to that may help a community, but we need help. I have never asked for a hand out and we always try and help others when we are able. My children need your help, I want them to be able to sleep in their own rooms, in their own space. I want my baby to be able to enjoy a bath at home, not have to go to Nana's or be in a kitchen sink. He loves to play in the bath and he can't at home.

Other Ways You Can Help

I am not asking for someone to give $100. I am not even hoping for $50 from one person. All I am asking is for $5 to $15 or $20, anything helps..

 
I realize that money is tight right now. Believe me, I understand as much as anyone! But any donation will help. And I will be so grateful for your generosity!!
 
If you cannot help fund, I would appreciate it if you could just share this link to people on your Facebook friend's list, or in your email list.
 
I appreciate all of the help and support already!
 
Thank you so much!

I appreciate all of the help and support already!
 
Thank you so much!

story:
Short Summary

Contributors fund ideas they can be passionate about and to people they trust. Here are some things to do in this section:

  • Introduce yourself and your background.
  • Briefly describe your campaign and why it’s important to you.
  • Express the magnitude of what contributors will help you achieve.

Remember, keep it concise, yet personal. Ask yourself: if someone stopped reading here would they be ready to make a contribution?

What We Need & What You Get

Break it down for folks in more detail:

  • Explain how much funding you need and where it’s going. Be transparent and specific—people need to trust you to want to fund you.
  • Tell people about your unique perks. Get them excited!
  • Describe where the funds go if you don’t reach your entire goal.

The Impact

Feel free to explain more about your campaign and let people know how the difference their contribution will make:

  • Explain why your project is valuable to the contributor and to the world.
  • Point out your successful track record with projects like this (if you have one).
  • Make it real for people and build trust.

Other Ways You Can Help

Some people just can’t contribute, but that doesn’t mean they can’t help:

  • Ask folks to get the word out and make some noise about your campaign.
  • Remind them to use the Indiegogo share tools!

And that’s all there is to it.

story:
BREW is a new (but simple) concept bar collaboration between veterans of the local bar and coffee biz. We'll feature an impressive selection of American canned craft beers with limited hand-selected offerings of seasonal / special release bottles and drafts. In addition to proudly pouring Bold Bean espresso, we'll feature rotating selections of our favorite roasters from around the country.

Our mission is to create a new bar experience in Five Points that fosters community and encourages social interaction while celebrating the American craftsman and the anti-commoditization of the things we enjoy. Beyond our carefully curated beers and espressos, our focus will be on atmosphere, experience and community. Five Points is home to several fantastic bars but BREW will be unlike anything the neighborhood has seen before and is currently missing - a modern yet unpretentious gathering place with an inspired aesthetic that encourages community and provides the perfect setting to taste and experience new things. Keep reading to learn about membership opportunities in the BREW social club.

We need your help to make BREW the best it can be and in exchange, you get to JOIN THE CLUB! We're trying to raise at least $10,000 to cover some of the build-out costs and we're offering some pretty sweet deals in return:

  • awesome silk-screened t-shirts!
  • BREW swag!
  • membership in the BREW CREW
  • FREE beer!
  • FREE coffee!
  • more...

Every penny earned will be used towards creating something truly unique and sought-after in the neighborhood so anything you can contribute will be put to good use.

We as a team have been involved with successful projects and businesses in Downtown and Riverside (including Burro Bar, Bold Bean Coffee, Burrito Gallery) and are eager to put our stamp on Jacksonville's historic Five Points. We look forward to working with the existing businesses (and those opening soon) to create even more options for the workers, shoppers, diners and revelers of Five Points. Together we can make a more vibrant neighborhood and your financial contribution allows us to do just that.

All are welcome in the hallowed halls (well, hall) of BREW but those who know the hidden secrets of the world (that nothing beats good craft beer and espresso) and have proven themselves worthy (CONTRIBUTE!) will be able to appreciate the perks of BREW CREW membership. 

The BREW Social Club is an elite group of discerning beer drinkers and espresso quaffers who enjoy craft beer from a can, the way mother nature intended it. Membership includes a limited edition koozie that gets you $1 off every can beer you purchase for 6 or 12 months. Become the envy of your peers when you brandish your faithful koozie and unlock not only valuable discounts but entry into members-only events like our soft opening party, tastings, tailgates, cookouts, bike rides, camping trips and more!


Uh, because they're awesome. Here's why:

  • aluminum cans block out 100% of light unlike bottles so they stay fresher longer
  • aluminum cans be crushed so they take up less space and are easily recyclable
  • many craft brewers are adopting the can over the bottle because they are easy to store and less likely to break in transit
  • you can cut the top off and voila, instant glass!
  • there's something unpretentious and nostalgic (and 'Merican!) about a can of beer

Don't worry, we aren't throwing the baby out with bathwater. BREW will also feature three carefully selected drafts and a rotating cast of seasonal and special release bottles.

Not a beer drinker? That's cool. Or perhaps like any red-blooded American, you simply aren't quite yourself without your periodic caffeine fix. We understand. Our espresso program is designed by none other than Bold Bean Coffee's head roaster, Chris! Suffice it to say he knows a thing or two about good coffee. We're proud to offer the fruits of his labor and additionally, he'll be on the hunt for great espressos from other craft roasters from around the country. If espresso is your thing and you are looking to expand your horizons, you'll appreciate the featured espresso options we'll offer!

And because while good coffee is fine by itself, but even better with something to nibble on, we've teamed up with Community Loaves and Dig Foods to offer handmade toast and jams you can't get anywhere else!

***

Click on the gallery tab above for a sneak peak inside BREW Social Club - Five Points!

We're proud to offer the fruits of his labor and additionally, he'll be on the hunt for great espressos from other craft roasters from around the country. If espresso is your thing and you are looking to expand your horizons, you'll appreciate the featured espresso options we'll offer!And because while good coffee is fine by itself, but even better with something to nibble on, we've teamed up with Community Loaves and Dig Foods to offer handmade toast and jams you can't get anywhere else!***Click on the gallery tab above for a sneak peak inside BREW Social Club - Five Points!

story:
Short Summary:


Update 11/14/2013 - New photos of north Cebu, courtesy from Roy Delez. Added photos on the purchase of the 1st Batch of Relief Goods.

Update 11/13/2013 - Thank you very much everyone for the overwhelming support!

---------------------

I'm Michael Cubos from Cebu Philippines. I'm asking for help for those people affected specially in north Cebu and Leyte. I am organizing a immediate relief operations this week to affected areas that are not yet reached.

The people in Visayas Philippines have been experienced a lot. A few weeks ago we had a 7.2 earthquake. Last week we got hit by a storm then a tornado. Last November 8, we got hit hard by the most powerful storm to ever hit land.

Many people died. A lot of dead bodies are still scattered on the streets and not yet recovered. It is estimated that about 10,000 people were killed. Many are homeless, without food and water. Most areas affected are still unreachable and badly need our help.

http://www.independent.co.uk/news/world/asia/typhoon-haiyan-most-powerful-storm-to-ever-hit-land-batters-philippines-with-235mph-winds-8926719.html

http://worldnews.nbcnews.com/_news/2013/11/09/21381516-typhoon-haiyan-officials-fear-death-toll-could-reach-10000

http://edition.cnn.com/2013/11/07/world/asia/philippines-typhoon-haiyan/index.html?hpt=hp_t2


What We Need:

  • We need as much money as we can get – but we are aiming to raise at least $2,000 dollars as soon as we can. Relief operations by various organizations takes several days to dispatch. We want to provide immediate assistance asap.
  • Funds raised will go towards providing relief operations to nothern Cebu (Bogo City and neighboring towns) and to Tacloban City.
  • Funds will be used to buy food, water, medicines and temporary shelters.


The Impact:

  • Your contribution will ensure that those affected will have all the help they need as soon as possible.
  • The sooner we get the funds, the faster we can deliver the relief specially to the far flung areas.
  • I will provide personal receipts and pictures of the relief goods purchased and during distribution.


Other Ways You Can Help:

  • You can also help by sharing this to your friends, family and other people you know.

story:
Communitas

< Latin; noun.
An unstructured community in which people are equal. An intense community spirit of great social equality, solidarity, and togetherness.

Mission Statement & Philosophy

The mission of “Communitas” is to form partnerships with women’s programs in the developing world, who produce handmade, artisanal, and often traditional goods that can be sold in Western markets.

The objective of Communitas is two fold. Firstly, to offer consumers one of a kind items that are sustainably and ethically made. Communitas wants locate, partner, and market unique quality products produced by women’s grassroots organizations that promote women’s economic empowerment and community development.

And secondly, Communitas hopes to encourage ethical and informed consumers. Consumers who understand that where and how they spend their money can make an impact in the world. Consumers who want to know that what they purchase is made with sustainable materials, and under not just fair, but above average working conditions.

Forming partnerships with women’s economic empowerment and skill development programs based in fairness and equality is an essential part of Communitas’s mission. At Communitas we believe human-beings both desire and are capable of progress. We believe that people, once given the resources, training, and opportunity to do so, are able to develop their own communities, socially, politically, and economically better than any outside organization, or aid package can. Don’t just teach a person to fish, bring them and their catch to the fish market!

Plan of Action

The first step towards achieving Communitas’s mission is taking an initial trip to Nepal to meet with women’s organizations, form partnerships, and purchase the first batch of items to bring back to the United States. The items would then be marketed in an online store/website that is currently being developed, as well as in select retail locations.

Nepal has been chosen as the pilot country primarily due to contacts already established with a local women’s organization that produces contemporary items using traditional Nepali dyeing and weaving techniques. The organization is locally run by a Nepali woman, requires the children of the women employed to attend school, and provides training in skills such as math, reading, writing, and sewing to the women they employ. Part of the goal of Communitas is to help these local organizations grow, to include more women, and discourage women from going abroad as domestic help, by providing them economic opportunity in their own countries.

Communitas will reserve 25% of proceeds from each item sold to be put in a fund towards a scholarship for top female academic performers from the communities in which Communitas has its partnerships, to attend university.  The focus on education was chosen because education is the most definite way to inspire and create the capacity for grassroots driven economic, social, and political progress. 

All funds raised that exceed our goal will go towards forming a second partnership with a women's development program in Ethiopia.

story:
I have a number of friends who own food trucks here in the Orlando, Florida area.  They have lamented that there is no national trade association to represent them and provide guidance in the ongoing battle with regulators who are constantly trying to limit their impact on the established brick-and-mortar restaurants with their powerful lobbyists.

My name is Mark Boyd and my background is in the marketing and promotions field.

I have spent over six months creating the American Food Truck Association (AFTA) to address all the pitfalls and hazards faced by the thousands of truck owners who are living the American dream of starting their own business feeding millions of nationwide foodies. 

The main features of AFTA membership are:

-  Sample workable food truck licensure regulations for communities 

-  Consultation with AFTA legal team regarding local regulatory issues

-  Incredible real-time online satellite truck tracking (Truck Trakker)

-  Emergency silent alarm summons responders to your exact location – warning decal

-  Two National Convention and Food Competitions in Orlando and San Francisco

-  Fast roadside assistance with location shown to dispatcher

-  Credit card reader with very low swipe rates (1.3%)

-  Product discounts for Members

-  Low health, truck, liability, business insurance

-  Buy and sell vehicle listings

-  Weekly trade and industry articles

-  Truck and Equipment financing

During the last six months I was able to assemble the various providers of the services for our members with a minimum of expense.  However, the best feature of our membership benefits is our Truck Trakker GPS transponder.  Each member is provided with a high-tech small electronic transponder that continually transmits the truck's location in near-real time. Any cell phone, tablet or PC can instantly locate every (member) food truck in America.  Currently, food trucks tweet their locations to their fans texting their location at the time.  This takes a huge amount of time during the day to keep current.  Truck Trakker removes this burden, and also serves as an emergency locator, crime deterrent, medical response, as well as an automatic texting capability.

The Truck Trakker technology involves intricate satellite GPS uplinks and a massive downlink to our website every ten minutes.  This technology is very expensive for us to implement and that is the purpose of our searching for funding with indiegogo.com.

When we are able to provide our technology vendors the roughly $15,000 to finalize the links between the truckers and their fan base, we will be the nation's first and best organization catering to the needs of an industry just waiting to explode.

If we are unable to raise the entire amount needed for technology completion, we will fund what we can to the technicians and launch AFTA on a "charter member" basis.  We would discount the membership fee in lieu of completion of the technology and then lock in the discounted fee permanently for the beta testing the charter members would be providing.

Listen, I'm a foodie and love dining at food trucks in the Orlando area.  It makes me do a slow burn to see how they are treated by community regulators in the downtown areas of so many cities.

Here's your chance to join me and provide food trucks across America quality legal advice and representation in attacking the unfair statutes that have been hastily employed by city councils who don't have a clue to the incredibly positive economic impact gourmet food trucks bring to urban living and working centers.

A business partner of mine has created a huge trade association (Florida Theme Attraction Assn) in the past and he has agreed to guide me in any areas I may need assistance.  I have lined up a top lawyer who has a track record in successfully challenging unjust civil regulations and have met with the owners of the Truck Trakker technology, as well as a major insurer who provides group insurance to associations. I have also met with Wells Fargo bank that will provide me with a credit card swipe rate far below the "Square" unit's 2.7% thus saving AFTA members between $4,000-$6,000 per year.

I know not everyone is in a position to contribute to our noble effort in this down economy, but you can still help by patronizing your regional food trucks and encouraging them to join AFTA.

Thanks, now, let's eat.

story:
I and few of my friends get together and make electronic projects that makes life easier for people. As of now we get 3D parts printed from outside which is very expansive.

As you know India has a lot of poor people as its citizen. These people are uneducated and earn their living through manual labor. Here it is very hot and humid in the summer and manual labor in this climate is very harmful for their health. Manual labor during the summer causes over 100 deaths per months in our city alone.

Me and some of my friends from school are trying to develop CHEAP TECHNOLOGY to make life a little easier for them. A 3D printer for prototyping would go a long way.

As of now we are working with rickshaw-pullers. We are prototyping solar powered fans which will keep them cool while they are pulling the rickshaw as well as when they are resting. We are also trying to make a gear system which will be cheap to produce and cheap to maintain as they do not make a lot of money.

We do not intend to sell the products to them for a profit. We are planning to charge them 20% less then our manufacturing cost.

story:
Mama Vilma's Home, San Pedro, Belize

Friends and family:

There are few places on this planet that are fully supplied with basic needs and appropriate support for true success.  As a nation, we struggle daily but we also have many programs in place to try to keep the weakest from slipping through the cracks.  I'd like to introduce you to Mama Vilma's Home, a relatively new NGO in San Pedro, Belize working to help keep abused women and children safe and supported.  https://www.facebook.com/mamavilmasfamilyhome

How it connects to me and then YOU!

I will be traveling to San Pedro in November and am passionate about giving back while I am there.  In speaking with Monica at MVH, they requested first aid kits for the teachers in their schools because they have no school nurses; they requested school supplies for the children; they have requested bedding items like sheets and pillow cases.

The Impact

This amazing group is so dedicated to helping these women and children that they take them into their own homes.  "The purpose of Mama Vilma’s Family Home is to provide disenfranchised families and children with temporary housing, food, medical care, counseling and education to foster their connection with the San Pedro community and assist with developing a strong family unit".  Their ultimate goal is to support the family to keep them together and HEALTHY versus sending the children to the overcrowded mainland orphanages.

Other Ways You Can Help

Please know that I realize that we are all facing tight financial situations and I completely understand if the timing is bad.  However, if you cannot contribute, would you please share this link with friends that might be interested?  I'd be so grateful!

Many thanks, All, and be well!

story:
Hello!

My name is Ryan Roadhouse. I am the owner/chef of Nodoguro. I started Nodoguro as a pop-up restaurant with my wife, Elena Roadhouse in the spring of 2014. We introduced Portland to experimental and creative Japanese Sousaku cuisine in a fun and eclectic setting.  It was born as a"kaiseki without the rules" pop-up from the internet with nothing more than a website and a DIY reservation system. We were asking our guests to purchase tickets in advance to my virtual restaurant, which became a reality in an empty dining room somewhere in the city, just once or twice a month. Nodoguro quickly evolved into a full-time 13 seat destination restaurant nestled inside of a hidden cafe space in a boutique grocery store on SE Hawthorne. We focus on providing a fun "dinner party" atmosphere, imaginative menus, and artistic decor. The best part is that our dining room has become  a space for the cultivation of wonderful friendships. 

Just as Nodoguro was named Portland Monthly's Restaurant of the Year for 2015, we learned that we would lose our restaurant space due to the closure of the grocery store we leased it from. During the time most assumed we would celebrate what we had accomplished with so little, we were actually scrambling to keep our little dream alive. With little hope of finding a new space on such a short timeline before it seemed we would shut down, we began to look for a new restaurant. I am very thankful to our friends at Ataula, Hanoak, and Renata for allowing us to treat their restaurants as our temporary home and keep Nodoguro alive, while we looked for permanent space. 

Today I would like to announce that our search has ended and we have just signed a lease on our new permanent home, in the historic Genoa restaurant space at 2832 SE Belmont in Portland, Oregon.

It may be a super cool idea, but let's face it, there is nothing glamorous or fun about operating a pop-up restaurant. The packing, loading, moving, cooking in an unfamiliar kitchen, and then, packing again is definitely not fun, but for us it was worth it every night in order to make our bootstrap restaurant dream a reality. I remember the relief we felt the night we didn't have pack our dishes up after taking the over the former Evoe space inside of  Pastaworks. It allowed Nodoguro to grow, mature, and plant little tiny roots, but I recall, wishing we could provide our guests with a bit more comfort and warmth than our space allowed. The upside of losing our restaurant space a couple months ago, is the opportunity it provided to create a space that fits our personality and offers greater comfort to our guests. 

With your contributions,we plan to remodel the beautiful Genoa restaurant space to feature a spacious 15 seat chef counter, which put you right in our preparation area similarly to how we served at The original Nodoguro. We also plan to have comfortable chairs with backs!!! Perhaps the most exciting part of our plan is to add an area we will call, "the Study". It is a place where you can hang out before or after dinner for a glass of wine or conversation. It will be our little library and we hope it will be the kind of place where you can relax, lose track of time, and maybe make some new friends. This area will also be open to guests who would like to come have snacks and drinks during our normal dinner service, as well. With your backing we hope to raise $35,000 to help our little dream live on and settle Nodoguro into its new home.

Thanks again for your support!


Yours,


Ryan and Elena Roadhouse

story:
Summary

The Hastings Independent Press (HIP) is a free fortnightly newspaper, run mainly on a voluntary basis by a group of local residents who know that Hastings is a unique place, with a character that deserves recognition. We aim to give a voice to the residents of Hastings and St Leonards to support a strong sense of community and to provide an impartial platform for debate about local issues. We encourage anyone who lives in Hastings and St Leonards to come and get involved.

The paper started back in January 2014, when a group of locals took matters into their own hands after becoming frustrated at the quality of local news coverage. We feel it’s important that a local paper should be community controlled, and written by people who live in and love Hastings. We also believe a local paper should serve its readers rather than its shareholders. That’s why the Hastings Independent is set up as a not-for-profit Community Interest Company, with all profits being invested back in to the company to help achieve its social aims.

These aims are:

1. To provide training, work experience and, in the long term, employment for local people who wish to work in journalism and the media industry

2. To raise awareness of, and to address, community issues

3. To promote citizenship, the arts and education.  

We’ve now been running for over two years and have just printed our 50th issue. To be honest, we’re sometimes amazed we’re still going. But we are, thanks to the support of our loyal advertisers, the commitment and hard work of our talented team of 50+ volunteers and the blood, sweat and tears of our long-suffering designer and advertising manager.

Getting the paper out each fortnight is a mammoth task, and they do everything from researching and writing articles, drawing cartoons, taking photos, creating crosswords, editing each section, designing the layout, uploading to the website, posting on Facebook and Twitter, responding to enquiries, training up new contributors, delivering the paper, liaising with stockists, liaising with advertisers, organising fundraising events and applying for grants. No wonder they look so haggard!

We’re well aware that we’re not perfect. There’s been more than the occasional typo in the paper, a few episodes of time travel ... and even a rogue shark spotting! Sometimes we haven't been able to fit in all the articles we've been sent, and sometimes we’ve fitted in something we really shouldn’t have. It’s been a steep learning curve, but what we’ve achieved, given the few resources we have, is astounding – and with your help we want to keep doing it.

What We Need & What You Get

If we can secure funding to help us cover our core costs, our volunteers can focus on what’s most important – producing the best newspaper they can. It’s hard for them to focus on research and writing when they’re also having to hold emergency fundraisers and trudge around town delivering papers in the rain.

We need to raise £15,000 to enable us to expand our current operation. Here’s what we plan to do with it:

1. We want to pay a distribution co-ordinator to do our deliveries, increasing reliability and freeing up our volunteers to focus on news.

2. We need to improve our new premises, which was kindly donated to us but needs some work. This would give us a central, professional venue from where we can run the paper, provide training for our volunteers, store all the equipment we need to design and produce the paper. 

3. We also need funding to help cover our core running costs such as printing and design. While the bulk of these are covered by advertising, sometimes there’s a shortfall. We’re unable to cover this with any grant money we’re awarded, as it’s a condition of most grants that they can’t be used for running costs.

Everyone who supports our crowdfunding campaign will become a friend of HIP and will be invited to any friends events we hold in the future. You can also choose a subscription or an advertisement as your reward. With a subscription, you’ll get the paper delivered direct to your door for a year. With an advert, your message will reach an estimated readership of 14,000 local people each fortnight.

Even if we don't reach our entire goal of £15,000, every penny you contribute will help us improve the running of the paper.

    The Impact

    The Hastings Independent has featured contributions from hundreds of local people of all ages and backgrounds over the last two years, including many students who have gained useful work experience. This has included articles, cartoons, photos, poems, recipes, profiles of local artists, music reviews, event listings, pages put together by locals schools, reports from residents overseas, and much more. 

    It’s not just a paper, it’s an important local service provider. At a time of uncertainty regarding media studies in Hastings, it’s vital that we continue to offer much-needed media training and work experience in the town. Many of our former volunteers have gone on to get jobs in journalism, communications and the community sector. Some have even gone on to write for national newspapers, thanks in part to the experience they gained at the paper. We’ve also managed to generate enough income to pay two part-time workers and hope to employ more.

    This opinionated paper is written by an opinionated community. Readers may not always agree or appreciate every article or feature, but if we cause a reaction we are doing our job. It’s important the town's voice is heard, and that includes everyone – if you disagree with something, we want to hear from you too.

    There are several sources of local news – but the Hastings Independent fills an important gap. It provides free community news and information for those who can’t afford to buy newspapers, or who lack access or confidence on the internet.

    The Hastings Independent deliberately gives the maximum space possible to promote community groups and their campaigns. In our coverage we try to be constructive and offer solutions – and never to sensationalise. With our expanding social media and new website, we aim to provide more interactive coverage and offer additional community services.

    Check out our recent coverage of the university campus closure protests, Suggs from Madness laying the last plank on the restored pier, the Victorian hot baths converted into a state-of-the-art skate park, and what people in Hastings think of the EU referendum.

    Risks & Challenges

    We’ve already wrestled with and overcome just about every risk and challenge possible in the last two years. Somehow we’ve managed to keep going, so we’re confident that we can continue to grow. However, we have now reached  a crux point, so it is vital that we ensure this crowdfunding campaign is successful to provide us with a more stable financial footing.

    We’re also now in a position to apply for funding from a range of other sources, so we’ll be aiming to secure additional grants, in particular to support our free training programme for our volunteers.

    Other Ways You Can Help

    If you can't contribute financially, there are other ways you can help:

    • Please help us get the word out and make some noise about our campaign by sharing it on Facebook and Twitter

    • If you’re interested in volunteering for the paper or providing content, written or artistic, please get in touch with us at volunteer@hastingsindependentpress.co.uk

Summary 


The Hastings Independent Press (HIP) is a free fortnightly newspaper, run mainly on a voluntary basis by a group of local
 residents who know that Hastings is a unique place, with a character 
that deserves recognition. We aim to give a voice to the residents 
of Hastings and St Leonards to support a strong sense of community and to provide an impartial platform for debate about local issues. We encourage anyone who lives in Hastings and St Leonards to come and get involved.


The
paper started back in January 2014, when a group of locals took
matters into their own hands after becoming frustrated at the quality
of local news coverage.
We
feel it’s important that a local paper should be community
controlled, and written by people who live in and love Hastings. We
also believe a local paper should serve its readers rather than
its shareholders. That’s why the Hastings Independent is set up as
a not-for-profit Community Interest Company, with all profits being
invested back in to the company to help achieve its social aims.

These
aims are:

1.
To provide training, work experience and, in the long term,
employment for local people who wish to work in journalism and the
media industry

2.
To raise awareness of, and to address, community issues

3.
To promote citizenship, the arts and education.  


We’ve
now been running for over two years and have just printed our 50th
issue. To be honest, we’re sometimes amazed we’re still going.
But we are, thanks to the support of our loyal advertisers, the
commitment and hard work of our talented team of 50+ volunteers
and the blood, sweat and tears of our long-suffering designer and
advertising manager. 


Getting
the paper out each fortnight is a mammoth task, and they do
everything from researching and writing articles, drawing cartoons,
taking photos, creating crosswords, editing each section, designing
the layout, uploading to the website, posting on Facebook and
Twitter, responding to enquiries, training up new contributors,
delivering the paper, liaising with stockists, liaising with
advertisers, organising fundraising events and applying for grants.

well aware that we’re not perfect. There’s been more than the
occasional typo in the paper, a few episodes of time travel ... and
even a rogue shark spotting! Sometimes
we haven't been able to fit in all the articles we've been sent, and
sometimes we’ve fitted in something we really shouldn’t have.

the few resources we have, is astounding – and with your help we

town delivering papers in the rain.

Here’s what we plan to do with it:

1.
We want to pay a distribution co-ordinator to do our deliveries,
increasing reliability and freeing up our volunteers to focus on
news.

2.
We need to improve our new premises, which was kindly donated to
us but needs some work. This would give us a central, professional
venue from where we can run the paper, provide training for our
volunteers, store all the equipment we need to design and produce the
paper.

printing and design. While the bulk of these are covered by
advertising, sometimes there’s a shortfall. We’re unable to cover
this with any grant money we’re awarded, as it’s a condition of
most grants that they can’t be used for running costs.

who supports our crowdfunding campaign will become a friend of HIP

door for a year. With  an advert, your message will reach an estimated readership of 14,000
local
people each fortnight.

if we don't reach our entire goal of £15,000, every penny you

The
Hastings Independent has featured contributions from hundreds of
local people of all ages and backgrounds over the last two years,
including many students who have gained useful work experience. This
has included articles, cartoons, photos, poems, recipes, profiles of
local artists, music reviews, event listings, pages put together by

are several sources of local news – but the Hastings Independent
fills an important gap. It provides free community news and
information for those who can’t afford to buy newspapers, or who
lack access or confidence on the internet. 


The
Hastings Independent deliberately gives the maximum space possible to
promote community groups and their campaigns. In our coverage we try
to be constructive and offer solutions – and never to
sensationalise. With our expanding social media and new website, we
aim to provide more interactive coverage and offer additional
community services.
Check
 out our recent coverage of the university campus closure protests, Suggs from Madness laying the last plank on the restored pier, the Victorian hot baths converted into a state-of-the-art skate park, and what people in Hastings think of the EU referendum.
Risks & Challenges

already wrestled with and overcome just about every risk and
challenge possible in the last two years. Somehow we’ve managed to
keep going, so we’re confident that we can continue to grow. However, we have now reached  a crux point, so it is vital that we ensure this crowdfunding campaign is successful to provide us with a more stable financial footing.

also now in a position to apply for funding from a range of other
sources, so we’ll be aiming to secure additional grants, in

you can't contribute financially, there are other ways you can help:



	Please help us

	volunteer@hastingsindependentpress.co.uk

story:
Our Story

Flushing, NY is the crossroads of the world -- where you can find amazing culture and people from around the globe.  We want to celebrate the unique food, fashion, and music found here as well as help the small businesses and entrepreneurs who are struggling to make ends meet.  Over the past decade, rising rents and major development projects have threatened to displace the small mom-and-pop stores who invested their blood, sweat, and tears into making our neighborhood prosperous.  What better way to celebrate their hard work and bring our community together than with a night market and social event -- Flushing Night Out! 

Flushing Night Out will feature food from local restaurants, the latest fashion from our business district, and live music from area artists. Many cities across the world already have night markets, which are social hubs for friends and family to gather and build community. Now, it's our turn!  Our dream is to bring together people from all walks of life and cultural backgrounds in celebration of our beloved community. Are we ready for a night market?  Flushing Night Out wants to prove that we are!  So let's make it happen. With your support this dream can come to life and be wildly successful for years to come!

Read more @NY1 TV News, DNAinfo, Brownstoner, Times-Ledger, SinoVision, Courier, Korea Times, Chronicle, and SingTao and our Facebook page.

What We Need & What You Get

Here's what your funding will help us get:

  • A beautiful venue (Flushing Town Hall)
  • Local artists performing live music
  • Sound equipment and supplies
  • Banners to advertise the market
  • T-Shirts for the market
  • Event insurance
Here's what you'll get in return:
  • The satisfaction of being a part of a positive community event that supports local small businesses and cultural diversity
  • Depending on your level of funding, advertisement for your business or brand
  • Free FNO T-Shirts
  • Personalized thank you emails and letters from the FNO team
  • Much, much more!

Community Impact

Flushing Night Out is not just a social event and night market, it helps promote:

  • Cultural diversity and equality
  • Support local artists and small businesses
  • A vibrant Flushing community

Challenges

To meet the high expectations of Flushing Night Out, we need to expand our capacity to organize this really fantastic event.  As a new organization, the Greater Flushing Chamber of Commerce, relies on the work of volunteers and the contributions of our members. Since this is the first time we're organizing a night market, there is always a risk that we not meet expections. However, we believe that as a team we can overcome these hurdles because:

  • While our team is small, it is comprised of focused, driven members that work tirelessly to get everything done.
  • The Greater Flushing Chamber of Commerce's network extends to many organizations that can help get the project moving.

Other Ways You Can Help Out

If you can't donate money but still want to help us out, that's great! Here's how:

  • Spread the word about our project and our crowdfunding campaign (Indiegogo has a lot of sharing tools to make this very easy!)
  • Come to Flushing Night Out and support local business owners
  • Volunteer your time to help plan and execute the event!

Thank you and see you at Flushing Night Out!

story:
"By 2050, there will be

more plastic than fish"

                                      -World economic forum

The Plastic Problem and the Solution You Can be Part Of

Plastic has crept into our lives over the last 60 years and seems impossible to avoid. From straws, to wrapping on our produce, plastic is used everywhere. Plastic doesn't go away, it just breaks down into smaller and smaller pieces. The Plastic Island in the Pacific Ocean is larger than the state of Texas and possibly as large as Russia.

But there is good news: cities have begun banning plastic bags, plastic water bottles, straws, and more. People are refusing straws in restaurants, bringing their own bags when they go grocery shopping, and trying to lessen their use of plastic. So much more can be done, and pretty easily with the right education and support. That’s where Tare comes in.

The Tare Shop is a community-focused business opening in the North End of Halifax in Fall 2018. We support people wanting to work towards a zero-waste lifestyle and minimize their use of plastic. Tare is both a zero-waste coffee shop and a store that sells bulk goods and zero-waste lifestyle items. Some of our favourite items are bamboo straws and toothbrushes, lids that turn mason jars into drinking cups, dental floss made from bamboo and packaged in refillable glass vials, and beeswax wraps for food storage. In our bulk section we will sell cooking, cleaning and beauty products (oils, vinegars, cleaning products, soaps, shampoo, conditioner as well as food staples such as flours, pasta and nuts). We also will offer workshops, a speaker series, and kids' educational programming. Educating and empowering choices are key cornerstones of our business philosophy.

Here's a sample of some of the products we are carrying and what they can replace:

Tare also hosts a shared workspace during the day, where locals can enjoy a coffee while getting some work done, and during the evening it is a space for yoga, presentations, and zero-waste classes and workshops.

How we work

In the store: You'll bring your own travel mug if you want your coffee or tea 'to go,' or you can use one of our mugs to enjoy your drink in-store at our window-seats or the communal table.

If you're here to shop, you'll either buy some of our cloth bags or mason jars, or bring your own to fill up on bulk goods. We also offer a wide range of reusable products such as bamboo toothbrushes, stainless steel straws, and beeswax wraps, all intended to help you minimize your plastic consumption. We work with our suppliers to ensure that those products are delivered to us with as minimal packaging as possible!

 

 

 

 

 

 

 

 

 

 

 

 

 

 

What we have achieved so far

Registered business

Check. We are a fully registered business within Nova Scotia. 

 

Social Media

Oh ya, we would not be anywhere with out the help from you lovely people and the support you have shown us on social media. @thetareshop

 

Website

You bet, if you have not given it a look, please do so. We are constantly providing free information on how to transition to a lower impact lifestyle.

 

Inventory

Now this is where things get interesting. We are currently fully stocked on our website and have a large selection of eco-friendly and reusable products to go with your Zero-Waste lifestyle. 

 

Location

This could not be any better! We are right at the corner of Cornwallis and Creighton – official address: 5539 Cornwallis.  

 

Funding

In addition to some private funds, Tare has secured loans from Futurepreneur and BDC which we are thrilled about! We are so grateful that these organizations believe in our business model and are hoping that this Indiegogo campaign helps us avoid having to make use of all that money.

 

How you can help

By backing this campaign you are not only changing how things have been done for the past 60 years, you are helping the world move to a brighter and cleaner future. If you are unable to back this project, it would mean the world to us (and the world) if you could share this Indiegogo campaign with your friends on social media, or scream it from your rooftop. No matter how small the contribution, it will still make a difference. And we can't thank you enough for that!

 

About Kate

The Tare Shop was dreamed and created by Kate Pepler, an avid zero-waster living in Halifax. Kate went to Dalhousie and graduated with a BA in Sustainability, Environmental Science, and a minor in Marine Biology. Upon completing her degree, she was feeling overwhelmed with the doom and gloom narrative, and spent the year after graduation figuring out what she could do for the planet and how she could make a difference. What emerged was her vision for Tare. Tare combines all of her passions – oceans, reducing plastic pollution, environmental education, and fostering community – into one venture. Kate can't do it alone though and has been astounded by the outpouring of support to help her vision come to life. Kate was recently highlighted in a Dal Alumni Profile. Read it here!

 

Risks and challenges

While there are now many zero waste bulk stores worldwide, this is the first zero-waste coffee shop/store/community hub in Nova Scotia. However, there has already been wonderful support for Tare, both from the media and the local community. 

We have held 5 pop-up shops and already sold over $3000 of zero-waste lifestyle products. The challenge will be in retaining the customer base after that initial excitement of our opening. 

Creating a community of like-minded individuals takes time. And we aim to support our growth and survival by offering educational weekend programs for kids, a high-quality bi-monthly speaker series, and do it yourself workshops where people can make and take home their own beauty and cleaning products. 

In addition, we feel that having the café will not only bring people into the store, but will also create a place for eco-conscious individuals to come together. Additionally, the store will bring people in who might then stay for a coffee and a treat.

Seen on

You read all the way to the bottom! Thank you so much for your support.
It means the world to us!

story:
HELP US SAVE THE TABARD!

We need to cover ourselves so please ensure you’ve read about our goal and understand that your donation (less Indiegogo fees) and validity of your perk are contingent on us securing majority ownership of the Tabard.

What's the Tabard Inn Employee Committee?

The Tabard Inn Employee Committee is comprised of current and former employees, and even some patrons who are concerned about the future of the Tabard.  We've come together to save the Tabard by growing employee ownership to keep Tabard in the hands of those who know it and love it.

How Will Contributions Help Save the Tabard?

Tabard Inn Employee Committee believes the Tabard belongs in the hands of those who know it and love it.  To preserve the Tabard and promote its continued success, we seek to grow employee ownership for 30% to a majority.
 
To grow employee ownership requires resources. We need your help.

Sounds a Bit Complicated. How Exactly Will This Work?

Our goal is to raise funds to increase employee ownership to protect the Tabard.  If we are unable to grow that ownership to secure a safe majority ownership, we will return your donations less Indiegogo fees, which could range between 4%-9%.  Also, keep in mind, the perk you receive for your contribution will only be valid and honored if we secure majority ownership.   If we are unable to secure majority ownership, your perk will not be valid.

If we are successful in our attempts to secure majority ownership, we ask for your patience.  We estimate that we will need up to 1 year after securing ownership to fulfill your perk, or begin fulfilling perks that are realized over time.

We know the next year could very well include a lot of extra work, but we're ready and excited to have you join our campaign to save the Tabard.  We can’t accomplish this without you!

Amazing Perks. It Almost Feels Like I'm Getting the Deal!

Well, let’s just say we consider this a mutually beneficial relationship; we love you and we hope you love us.  While trying to remember this is a fundraiser, we’ve tried our best to be fair and offer unique perks that express our gratitude.

We want to give you the world, but Indiegogo only allows us 20 perks at a time.  We've got plenty more ideas and offerings so if you're desiring something that isn't on the list, e-mail us at savethetabard@gmail.com and we'll try to figure something out.

For now, here are just a few of the incentives you could receive:

* A commemorative Rooms of the Tabard print.  This print will feature one photo from each of Tabard's 38 uniquely designed rooms. Photos will be taken by an Architectural Digest photographer.

* Personally designed cocktail on Tabard's cocktail menu for one year with a special recognition.  Please keep the names classy!

* 1 year membership to Tabard's Chef's Table, Salon Series, or Wine Club.

* Ink a Tabard employee with the Save the Tabard Logo

* Penthouse for a romantic weekend getaway.

* Private Tabard dinner party at your home.

* Tabard wedding or renewal of vows ceremony and reception.

As these and other perk categories are snatched up, we’ll be adding more!  Remember, we only retain your contribution, less Indiegogo fees and you only get your perk if we succeed in securing majority ownership.

Why is the Tabard Worth Saving?

Customers often share their personal stories of how they came to love Tabard.  Each time, it just reinforces what we believe - that Tabard is a special place. It's the perfect mix of character and class, perfection and experimentation, and comfort and edge. But that didn't happen by accident.

While valuing and empowering employees, the Tabard philosophy has always put the customer first. As a result, employees constantly collaborate looking for ways to improve the Tabard. We learn, teach, experiment, share and challenge one another.  In the end, customers benefit from an even better Tabard experience.

We know we're a little different. We like to think that's part of our charm.  No televisions in our hotel rooms.  Real books on our bookshelves. Thought-provoking artwork adorn our walls. We’ve always prided ourselves on our diverse and talented staff.  Generations of families are employed at the Tabard. If it feels like a family, that's because we are a family.

Tabard doesn't suppress character; it encourages expression.  No matter your background, your vestures, or your beliefs, the Tabard welcomes you.

We believe shareholders and employees aren't the only ones who have invested in the Tabard.  We know our patrons love the Tabard; some of you have been visiting us for over thirty years.  Now, that's an investment!  We realize when you choose the Tabard that you are contributing toward our success.  That is why we express our gratitude after you've shown your patronage.

Devoted employees and loyal patrons have made the Tabard a DC institution.

Other Ways You Can Help

We realize not everyone is in a position to donate, but even small donations help.  We will do our best to recognize all who have contributed - big and small.

There are other ways you can help!!

  • Sign. Please sign our petition at http://tabard.coworker.org.
  • Visit. Please support the employees and the Tabard through your patronage during this difficult time. Feel free to give the employees a few words of encouragement!  We could use a little love!
  • Spread the word. Use the Indiegogo share tools to pass this along to a friend.  We sure would appreciate it.

Save the Tabard Support Party

For those in Washington, D.C. and the surrounding area be sure to stay tuned for details on our Save the Tabard Support Party!

Questions?

E-mail us at savethetabard@gmail.com.
story_txt:
HELP US SAVE THE TABARD!
We need to cover ourselves so please ensure you’ve read about our goal and understand that your donation (less Indiegogo fees) and validity of your perk are contingent on us securing majority ownership of the Tabard.
What's the Tabard Inn Employee Committee?
The Tabard Inn Employee Committee is comprised of current and former employees, and even some patrons who are concerned about the future of the Tabard.  We've come together to save the Tabard by growing employee ownership to keep Tabard in the hands of those who know it and love it.
How Will Contributions Help Save the Tabard?
Tabard Inn Employee Committee believes the Tabard belongs in the hands of those who know it and love it.  To preserve the Tabard and promote its continued success, we seek to grow employee ownership for 30% to a majority.
 
To grow employee ownership requires resources. We need your help.

Sounds a Bit Complicated. How Exactly Will This Work?
Our goal is to raise funds to increase employee ownership to protect the Tabard.  If we are unable to grow that ownership to secure a safe majority ownership, we will return your donations less Indiegogo fees, which could range between 4%-9%.  Also, keep in mind, the perk you receive for your contribution will only be valid and honored if we secure majority ownership.   If we are unable to secure majority ownership, your perk will not be valid.
If we are successful in our attempts to secure majority ownership, we ask for your patience.  We estimate that we will need up to 1 year after securing ownership to fulfill your perk, or begin fulfilling perks that are realized over time.
We know the next year could very well include a lot of extra work, but we're ready and excited to have you join our campaign to save the Tabard.  We can’t accomplish this without you!
Amazing Perks. It Almost Feels Like I'm Getting the Deal!
Well, let’s just say we consider this a mutually beneficial relationship; we love you and we hope you love us.  While trying to remember this is a fundraiser, we’ve tried our best to be fair and offer unique perks that express our gratitude.
We want to give you the world, but Indiegogo only allows us 20 perks at a time.  We've got plenty more ideas and offerings so if you're desiring something that isn't on the list, e-mail us at savethetabard@gmail.com and we'll try to figure something out.

story:
About the Geekery

Purveyor of Geekery was started when my husband and I decided to start our family. Instead of continuing in my corporate world addiction, I wanted to use my powers for good instead of evil*. In the last year and half I've worked with business owners around the world (yes: world, CRAZY! check out my client map here) getting their businesses in gear, from marketing to consulting to training. In my spare time I've helped non-profits with their engagement strategies like the jQuery Foundation, mentor people in new skill sets and drink coffee to keep up with the pace. I want to continue doing this, only on a slightly larger scale. 

* Evil: [ee-vuhl] adjective Used to describe businesses who use disclaimers as a way to negate their actual offer and rip customers off via small print. The dark side really didn't have cookies, just a Keurig. No thanks.

What About the Big Girl Pants

While focusing on everyone else's business, Purveyor of Geekery has neglected to take itself seriously as its own business entity. Neglected. Depressed. Miserably and Lonely, the little business sulks in the corner. It's time to start taking her seriously.

1. PoG needs a new computer. Seriously, the old one was on it's last leg years ago and I've been borrowing a family member's computer to make it by for the last year. You can only borrow something for so long before it crosses the line from "borrowing" to "taking."

Worse case scenario, I'll throw the components of my old laptop into a barebones case that it is compatible with. The worse case scenario is reflected in the funding amount set. Any money over the amount I am trying to raise will go towards better equipment. The idea of not having to duck tape a computer together would be fantastic! 

2. Purveyor of Geekery needs a home, officially. I'm looking at space in a start-up incubator in the county over which also just happens to have non-astronomical Business Tax Fees as the city I would have to register if I filed locally. 

Any and all funds will be put towards these two areas, above or below the amount set.

What You Get

Perks! Please check out the different levels to the right. By helping my fund, you have the chance to get design, consultation, or training for yourself, friends and family or the non-profit of your choice. Contributions of $100 or more will get a gift certificate with matching funds from me towards the same, so for instance $100 becomes a $200 gift certificate. 

The Impact

Purveyor of Geekery has helped over 500 clients last year with their business goals. That is an insane number to think of: almost two people a working day on the road to no longer being reliant on corporate culture to make ends meet. Without a functioning computer, this is no longer feasible, obviously. Moving forward it will continue bring affordable services but will focus more on self sustainability, or teaching business owners how to raise successful businesses on their own as well. 

Can't Contribute Financially?

No worries! If you could help spread the word to your network and follow us on ours, that would be great!

Facebook

Twitter

Addictive, Do Not Click Me.

story:
SOTR Raising Awareness for Pregnancy and Infant Loss

My name is Katy Larsen. I am a mother of three, but I only mother 2 on Earth. I lost my middle child Hannah to stillbirth in September 2009. I began gifting items to women that I would craft myself in an attempt to heal someone elses's heart. I didn't realize at the time how healing it was to my own heart.

I soon opened an Etsy shop and began selling Remembrance Items for these babies lost. I used the proceeds to continue to gift other families. I made memory boxes for all the hospitals in my state with a Labor & Delivery Department, 21 in all, because Hannah was born in an ER. It was horrific. But I was beginning to heal and with the birth of my third child I began to see some hope again. And that reflected in my shop as well. The side by side co-existence of hope and grief is most definitely depicted there.

This year I decided to try to take my venture a step farther and become an LLC with a real operating website. If I was to continue to help people and continue to raise awareness, I needed to grow. And so recently I joined forces with a marketing company called Vocus. This is where the funds come in. Marketing your company is not cheap but I see no other way to spread the word, spread the love, spread the hope. Losing a baby during or after pregnancy is devastating and my mission for my daughter is to help as many families as I can. Recentlt they issued my first Press Release.

The funds will be use to continue the marketing process, to update some of the equipment we are working with and MOST IMPORTANTLY reach out and raise awareness. Pregnancy and Infant loss is taboo. Nobody wants to talk about a dead baby.....unless you have one.

The impact on these families is immense. It validates the life of that child to know that just one person has remembered his/her birthday or due date or day that they passed. One would be incredibly surprised to learn of how common Pregnancy and Infant Loss is, yet how you never hear of it. 1 in 4 pregnant women will suffer a loss. That is 25% of pregnant women.

Startling, right?

I would be estatic at the outreach this could create. Ideas are floating through my head at more and more ways of reaching bereaved parents and I hope you will believe in me and my cause and contribute. You will be impacting the lives of hundreds, hopefully thousands, of women.

If you can't contribute to my cause, you can still help! Tell your friends and use the share tools!
