story:
Thanks for checking out our project.

This project will go on regardless of how much it will raise. However, without your support it will take much much longer. Please donate now.

 

OUR STORY

We're music fans and technology nerds, and we’re concerned about the current chaotic state of music. The digital world is helping more musicians make music but provides less revenue for them to make a living. Now, mobile technology is here, and we believe mobile can completely transform the music experience and provide new revenue streams that sustain Artists. We started Adva Mobile when we saw a way to help Artists connect with their fans on mobile phones, engage their fans where they are (on their phones!) and give them tools to sell music, tickets and merchandise, and let them keep all the money themselves.

We built our first version in 2008 and over 1,400 bands have found us and signed up. We give artists everything they need to take advantage of mobile – phone friendly web sites, Apps, text messaging, downloads, tour dates, and a storefront to sell stuff to their fans. Most of the bands choose our free service -- we think every band should be able to take advantage of this new mobile technology. More of them are starting to upgrade to our paid services. The back end software and databases of our site works great and provides the most complete mobile marketing functionality and tools available to Artists anywhere.

 So we are doing amazing things for artists to help them connect with their fans and make money and have music careers. We've made some really cool custom mobile websites (including one for our friends at Constant Contact) and Apps and have run some great campaigns that get fans to sign up and download music. They're just starting to make purchases on mobile phones. The artists are excited and believe we are giving them a good service and a path to their future, which they know is mobile.

 

Lately though, they’re telling us that their mobile site is not cool and our web site dashboard to manage their mobile campaigns is dated – thus, they are reluctant to use it. Some of our partner opportunities are turned off because the portal looks so old, and one has refused to partner with us until we display current design standards. It’s like what Steve Jobs said: Great Products are useful (check), emotionally satisfying (check) and attractive to look at (definitely uncheck!). So we need to fix that.

  WHAT WE NEED & WHAT YOU GET

We're looking to raise $6,500 to design a modern image for our webpages and layout the user interface that manages our software in a modern, attractive look that will be appealing to our customers. We need to hire a graphics web designer with experience in user interface technologies to take our existing mobile marketing services platform and make it easy to use and beautiful to look at.This individual or team will deliver approximately 30 webpages laid out with the user interface designed for the task -- uploading music to download, entering concert information, managing fans, etc. Their deliverable is HTML and CSS files that execute the design. This design next needs to be tied into the existing backend database, so that, for example, when you enter a tour date, it shows up correctly on the database so that it shows up correctly on a fans mobile phone. We need to hire a software pro expert in .NET/ASP programming to integrate the front end with the back end. We financed the company so far out of our own pockets, sweat, and credit. The money raised here will go directly to hiring a contract design and user interface professional that can deliver an outstanding user interface experience for the services we provide.  If we raise more than our goal, we'll use the money to improve the platform with more features, and marketing.

 

As long as we're working with a design expert, we would also have him design new mobile web templates for our free and paid subscribers. The current mobile designs are functionally amazing but boring to look at, and artists are not excited to promote their own mobile web presence when it looks so lame. For artists that choose our free service,even they should have a design that is current and modern.

 

 

 We're offering a wide range of perks to our Indie GoGo pledgers. If you're an artist or someone in the music industry, you can take advantage of the paid versions of our mobile platform at terrific discounts. You’ll get to work with the new platform you helped create! If you're part of a business that can benefit from mobile advertising, our mobile websites display thousands of ads each day and we can offer you mobile advertising targeted to the music demographic -- 18 to 34-year-olds. Friends that help us out get to claim support for our mission and we’ve thought of a bunch of fun stuff from Adva Mobile to thank you. Take a look and make your pledge now! And THANK YOU SO MUCH!

 

OTHER WAYS YOU CAN HELP!

If you'd like to see this become a reality as much as we do, but can't make a pledge (or already have), please share this with everyone you know! Spread the word via Facebook/Twitter/blog and tell your friends about our mission. IndieGoGo has some great sharing tools.

story:
Our Project

We are a group of passionate garden and sustainable-living enthusiasts in the small rural hilltown of Plainfield, Massachusetts. We have established a relationship with our local Franklin Land Trust to use some of their pristine farm land to create a community garden. This land, also known as the Guyette Farm, was gifted to the Franklin Land Trust by Eveyln Guyette and is permanently protected from development. We seek to create a beautiful and functional agricultural space for community members to use and enjoy, as a continuation of the long farming history of the land by the Guyette family.

Our community garden seeks to fill an important void in our area: access of gardening land for those in transition or without land, or for those who need extra support such as education and resources to build organic, nutrient dense soil. In addition, we are in need of more community building activities to strengthen our neighborhood ties in an otherwise isolating landscape. Furthermore, the community garden establishes public space for group garden projects to benefit the community at large.

Last year we plowed a quarter acre and cover cropped the area in preparation for the garden. This year will be our first season of growing food crops. We are welcoming people to acquire plots for personal gardens in half of the plowed land. In the other half, we are initiating shared community projects. This year, some of these community projects include: seed saving to create a local seed bank; growing vegetables for our local elementary school and for the food pantry; sustainable growing demonstrations using Permaculture and Grow Biointensive techniques. 

Last year we invited local experts and held workshops on pruning berries and on sheet mulching. These workshops supported our intention to re-establish and maintain the heirloom raspberries and blueberries that were part of the Guyette family's garden. This year, we hope to continue to provide workshops on a variety of gardening practices, such as hand pollination of winter squash, basic seed saving, and more. We also hope to use garden produce for healthy cooking instruction.

Your contributions will help us with the start-up costs of the Guyette Farm Community Garden. Our priorities from funding are to pay for compost and amendments to build a nutrient dense soil composition, and to pay for needed fencing to protect the crops from wildlife feasting. Any additional funds will be used for creating a watering system.

 

How You Can Help

Please consider giving whatever amount you can. Every little bit helps, even if it's $1 or $5.  Please look at the "Perks" in the boxes on the right side of this page to see what we will give back to you when you are able to give $10, $25, $50, $150, $300 or more. 

The funds we raise from your contributions will focus on these garden start-up needs:

1. Compost for the quarter acre: $500 estimation including already inquired discounts

2. Orgnaic Amendments for the garden: $500 estimation. 

We hope to build a nutrient dense soil with time. And we hope that by providing compost and amendments, we will make it more appealing for those without access, and easier for gardeners to create flourishing gardens.

3. Basic Fencing: $750 estimation for metal fence posts and metal grid fencing.

Extra Funds-- Watering System: Any extra funds from this campaign will go towards the set-up of a watering system which involves pumping from the nearby spring with piping and hoses that connect to the garden. Estimated $1000 cost.

Even if we do not reach our campaign goal of $1,750 to cover compost, amendments, and fencing, we will still go ahead with our plans for the community garden this season.

If you would like to make a tax deductible donation, you can donate directly to Franklin Land Trust, with a memo about supporting the Community Garden. . 

The Impact

Food insecurity and environmental degradation are major concerns for people all over the world. I believe that now, more than ever, we need to act to change the social and economic divide supported by systems of exploitation. Taking charge of local food production is an important act of connection with land, earth's resources, labor, and community. Creating this community garden is an example of dedicated action, which will increase the health of people, communities, and our environment. 

John Jeavons, my teacher and pioneer of Grow Biointensive mini-farming says, "All we need to do is to start with one growing bed and tend it well, and we have begun the exciting, expanding, giving process of enlivening and healing the Earth and ourselves."

 

Our Groundbreaking

On Saturday, May 12, 2012, we will be having the groundbreaking for our garden. We will have activities from 10 am to 2 pm. The following is the schedule of activites:

• 10:00: introduction to the garden

• 10:30: plowing the field with plow and oxen, led by local Plainfield resident.

• 11:30: scything demonstration

• 1:00: tool sharpening demonstration/workshop

All day: guided hikes, plant sale, and baby lambs!

We welcome you to come join us at our garden site on this day, to enjoy the festivities and to learn more about what we are doing. If you've donated $50 or more, you can come pick up your free plant.

 

Other Ways You Can Help

A monetary donation is not the only way you can help. Donations of tools and your time and labor to get our garden off to a good start are greatly appreciated. In addition, we appreciate your spreading the word of our campaign to others who may be able to help out,  or spreading the word to inspire others and to continue the ripple effect of positive change.
story_txt:
Our Project
We are a group of passionate garden and sustainable-living enthusiasts in the small rural hilltown of Plainfield, Massachusetts. We have established a relationship with our local Franklin Land Trust to use some of their pristine farm land to create a community garden. This land, also known as the Guyette Farm, was gifted to the Franklin Land Trust by Eveyln Guyette and is permanently protected from development. We seek to create a beautiful and functional agricultural space for community members to use and enjoy, as a continuation of the long farming history of the land by the Guyette family.
Our community garden seeks to fill an important void in our area: access of gardening land for those in transition or without land, or for those who need extra support such as education and resources to build organic, nutrient dense soil. In addition, we are in need of more community building activities to strengthen our neighborhood ties in an otherwise isolating landscape. Furthermore, the community garden establishes public space for group garden projects to benefit the community at large.
Last year we plowed a quarter acre and cover cropped the area in preparation for the garden. This year will be our first season of growing food crops. We are welcoming people to acquire plots for personal gardens in half of the plowed land. In the other half, we are initiating shared community projects. This year, some of these community projects include: seed saving to create a local seed bank; growing vegetables for our local elementary school and for the food pantry; sustainable growing demonstrations using Permaculture and Grow Biointensive techniques. 
Last year we invited local experts and held workshops on pruning berries and on sheet mulching. These workshops supported our intention to re-establish and maintain the heirloom raspberries and blueberries that were part of the Guyette family's garden. This year, we hope to continue to provide workshops on a variety of gardening practices, such as hand pollination of winter squash, basic seed saving, and more. We also hope to use garden produce for healthy cooking instruction.
Your contributions will help us with the start-up costs of the Guyette Farm Community Garden. Our priorities from funding are to pay for compost and amendments to build a nutrient dense soil composition, and to pay for needed fencing to protect the crops from wildlife feasting. Any additional funds will be used for creating a watering system.
 


How You Can Help
Please consider giving whatever amount you can. Every little bit helps, even if it's $1 or $5.  Please look at the "Perks" in the boxes on the right side of this page to see what we will give back to you when you are able to give $10, $25, $50, $150, $300 or more. 
The funds we raise from your contributions will focus on these garden start-up needs:
1. Compost for the quarter acre: $500 estimation including already inquired discounts
2. Orgnaic Amendments for the garden: $500 estimation. 
We hope to build a nutrient dense soil with time. And we hope that by providing compost and amendments, we will make it more appealing for those without access, and easier for gardeners to create flourishing gardens.
3. Basic Fencing: $750 estimation for metal fence posts and metal grid fencing.
Extra Funds-- Watering System: Any extra funds from this campaign will go towards the set-up of a watering system which involves pumping from the nearby spring with piping and hoses that connect to the garden. Estimated $1000 cost.
Even if we do not reach our campaign goal of $1,750 to cover compost, amendments, and fencing, we will still go ahead with our plans for the community garden this season.
If you would like to make a tax deductible donation, you can donate directly to Franklin Land Trust, with a memo about supporting the Community Garden. . 
The Impact


Food insecurity and environmental degradation are major concerns for people all over the world. I believe that now, more than ever, we need to act to change the social and economic divide supported by systems of exploitation. Taking charge of local food production is an important act of connection with land, earth's resources, labor, and community. Creating this community garden is an example of dedicated action, which will increase the health of people, communities, and our environment. 
John Jeavons, my teacher and pioneer of Grow Biointensive mini-farming says, "All we need to do is to start with one growing bed and tend it well, and we have begun the exciting, expanding, giving process of enlivening and healing the Earth and ourselves."
 


Our Groundbreaking
On Saturday, May 12, 2012, we will be having the groundbreaking for our garden. We will have activities from 10 am to 2 pm. The following is the schedule of activites:
• 10:00: introduction to the garden
• 10:30: plowing the field with plow and oxen, led by local Plainfield resident.
• 11:30: scything demonstration
• 1:00: tool sharpening demonstration/workshop
All day: guided hikes, plant sale, and baby lambs!
We welcome you to come join us at our garden site on this day, to enjoy the festivities and to learn more about what we are doing. If you've donated $50 or more, you can come pick up your free plant.
 
Other Ways You Can Help
A monetary donation is not the only way you can help. Donations of tools and your time and labor to get our garden off to a good start are greatly appreciated. In addition, we appreciate your spreading the word of our campaign to others who may be able to help out,  or spreading the word to inspire others and to continue the ripple effect of positive change.

story:
Mandy Harper began with the idea of Wholesome Bakery back in 2008 in her very own kitchen. Mandy loved treats, but she was picky: she wanted goodies free of dairy, soy, eggs, wheat, and refined sugars; and they couldn't taste like dust. This was no easy task, but Mandy was determined: if no one else was making yummy cookies and treats up to her standards, she would do it herself! Thus, Wholesome Bakery was born.

Wholesome Bakery knows there are many different diets out there, and many people with allergies to different ingredients. Wholesome Bakery is about making delicious treats that all people, no matter what their diet, may enjoy. There is no wheat, no soy, no eggs, and no dairy in Wholesome Bakery's treats because these are all very common allergens, as well as zero refined sugars. Only wholesome ingredients and natural sweeteners are used. Those are Wholesome Bakery's standards: No junk, and no ingredients devoid of nutritional value.


Wholesome Bakery has been baking goodie after goodie, unrelenting in the quest for the best-tasting, most mouth-watering, least complicated treat. Wholesome Bakery uses local, organic ingredients, the lowest-level gluten flour, and low-glycemic sweeteners. The results, after years of hard-work (and lots of taste-testing) are delicious treats that taste like treats!


What began as goodies for a health-conscious individual years ago has blossomed into a full-scale bakery. Wholesome Bakery needs help taking its next big step: opening a retail location so everyone knows where to find our goodies!

Wholesome Bakery, right now, operates out of a commercial kitchen in the Mission District and is sold at numerous coffee shops, cafes, and grocery stores all over San Francisco. We have just started to expand outside of the city and this money will help with that even more. The dream has always been a retail location, where Wholesome Bakery can grow. Wholesome Bakery is now bigger than Mandy, and big enough to fill its own space. Cookies, bars, brownies, cupcakes, doughnuts, even ice cream--these are all part of Wholesome Bakery's vision. This vision can become a reality if the Bakery can raise enough money to move into a retail location and get down to business: providing customers and treat-enthusiasts with fresh deliciousness. Wholesome Bakery needs to fulfill its potential, and Wholesome Bakery needs to be accessible. If you taste one cookie you'll agree: Wholesome Bakery is the cookie of the future.

  • The goal is $30,000: Equipment, permits, build-out, and all the costs associated with the growth of a small business
  • Perks: Amazing treats that are wheat-free, dairy-free & egg-free, soy-free, yeast-free, trans-fat free, low glycemic, hormone-free and GMO free. Made with organic, local & sustainable ingredients and ridiculously addicting.

Wholesome Bakery wants to save the world from bad, junky, empty sweets. Even if you can't contribute to our financial goal, look for Wholesome Bakery cookie sandwiches across the city and try them yourself! Spread the word and enjoy!

Below are pictures of some of the RAD perks we are offering.

The Limited Edition Cool Try for Wholesome Bakery T-shirt designed by local San Francisco artist Ryan De La Hoz; the master mind behind CoolTry.net

A preview of the official 2014 Ladies of Wholesome Bakery Calendar. It will keep you smiling all year long!

Front Cover

January thru April Preview

May thru August Preview

September thru December Preview

Back Cover

story:
Short Summary

The Bun Always Rises is a licensed residential bakery in Lyla & Jules' very own kitchen in Northampton, MA. Help us take our business a HUGE leap forward by going wholesale! A wholesale license will let us source our products to grocery markets & stores!

We built our humble bakery with a commitment to providing local, organic, vegan & gluten-free baked goods through sliding-scale costs. Our specialty is vegan challah which we bake every Friday and (once the warmth arrives, we will) deliver by bike.

What have we done so far? One wedding and one to come, numeous birthday cakes, a full season at two fabulous farmer's markets, Shabbos dinner deliveries, and so much more!

In fact, our challahs, cinnamon buns, cakes, cookies, breads, muffins and more have become so popular that we've decided to go wholesale! This means we can venture beyond deliveries and our farmer's market tables, and start sourcing to local groceries & stores in the area.

What We Need

$300 will get us our Massachusetts wholesale license!

$150 will get us necessary prints of product labels and signage!

$150 will get us more baking equitpment (quadrupling our products = building an industrial cooling rack, etc!) 

What You Get

Hopefully, a warm feeling that you've allowed us to engage with our community with a stronger presense. Check out the side bar on the right to find out how we can express our gratitude for your contributions :)

The Impact

Getting a wholesale license means a lot of great things.

It means that we can make challah available in this area of Western Massachusetts (of which there's a dire lack!).

It means you are supporting a beautiful, alternative economy that we're trying to cultivate. Because all our products are sliding-scale (aka- 'pay what you can'), your ability to help us in turn means that we will be able to continue providing affordable organic local breads & baked goods.

Above all, a wholesale license will allow us to sell our sliding-scale vegan baked goods DAILY at Food For Thought Books- a not for profit collectively run Bookstore in Amherst, MA. (Foodforthoughtbooks.com)

With Love

We love you! We pitch this fundraising effort humbly and with immense gratitude for your time scrolling through the page. Every contribution counts. We thank you with sticky fingers & flour-spotted clothes for anything you are able to give, your good wishes much included.

In rising~

Lyla & Jules

story:
The Concept

South of the Border has been created to change the way people experience cities. We want to give locals and tourists alike an opportunity to get to know Sydney at a deeper level by going to places not on the tourist trail, but those with heart and soul. Just like Redfern.

We’ve created an incredible 3 hour walking experience in the Sydney suburb of Redfern. Small groups of no more than 10 people will get to hear the amazing stories you’ve perhaps heard about but never had the chance to fully engage with. You’ll meet the local heroes that make the community tick. You’ll see first-hand the amazing culture, local craftsmen and art that make Redfern buzz.

Why our work is important

South of the Border’s mission is to break down stereotypes and challenge misperceptions that exist about Redfern. We’ll be showing a real picture of Redfern, and we think you’ll be amazed by the vibrant, welcoming community.

While we’re creating innovative tourism experiences, our dream is that tourism can become a catalyst for positive change in urban communities. That’s why South of the Border is a social enterprise that proudly supports a number of grassroots community initiatives. When you join a South of the Border Redfern experience, you can be sure that your money is supporting the community. Creating real shared value for you and the local community.

We need your support!

To turn this vision into reality we need your support! We’re seeking to raise $8,500 to get South of the Border off the ground.

Whatever your budget and wherever you are, there are loads of great perks designed especially for you to enjoy! Become a Cheer Leader for $20 and you’ll receive an original photographic artwork from Redfern. Check out these awesome one-off vintage Polaroids!  

For those of you in Sydney, we’d love you to join our Redfern tour. Become our travel buddy for only $50! Or even better, bring a friend along too and you can both enjoy the tour for only $80!

There are loads of other perks available for all our special supporters. Get behind South of the Border today!

The Innovation Process

We’ve had an amazing journey so far, having worked on creating South of the Border throughout 2012. The Founders are extremely passionate about the potential for tourism to be sustainable and nourishing for local communities. And breaking down some of the barriers that separate positive connections. In creating South of the Border they’ve taken a human-centred approach by incorporating feedback into every step of the design and creation process.

This began back in February 2012, when Nathan & Baptiste joined Nobel Laureate, Muhammad Yunus, for the Social Business Week workshop in Singapore. Prof. Yunus and his team made us dream...

On returning to Sydney, the guys were fortunate enough to come across the amazing service designers at specialist firm, Huddle Design. The team worked through many service design innovation workshops. Nathan Welch and his team made us believe…

Off again we travelled (it’s great to work in the travel industry!), this time to seek advice and best practice on two key focus areas. Firstly, the guys wanted to experience walking ‘tours’ in a number of different cities to test the status quo. To go way beyond and seek innovation points. Secondly, Nathan sought the sage advice of a number of social enterprises, to develop community engagement and to deeply understand how to ensure sustainability in the community. Aarti, Inir and Chris made us concentrate…

Over the last couple of months, the South of the Border team have been running a series of prototype tours in Redfern. This has been at different stages of the experience’s development to incorporate feedback, to test our assumptions. Thanks to all those who have participated. We love you guys! Our friends have made us realise anything is possible…

FAQ

Who are the South of the Border Founders?

Nathan Wiltshire is from Sydney, having spent a number of years working in the tourism industry. He’s passionate about tourism as a catalyst for positive change . And Baptiste Bachellerie, an adopted Parisian, has come to Sydney to see how he can make a real difference. Plus the amazing South of the Border team – Jess, Mette, Laura, Emil, Hasan, Stella & Caroline – these guys and gals are truly special.

When will South of the Border begin tours?

We’ll be starting our Redfern experience in early February 2013.

When will I be able to claim my Redfern experience?

We’ll be running a number of walking experiences in Redfern throughout February 2013. There will be weekday and weekend schedules to chose from. Dates to be released mid-January.

What happens if I am unable to attend any of the tour dates?

There will be many dates to chose from. In the unlikely event that you cannot attend any dates in February, we will either offer you a date in March, or another great perk such as lunch with the Founders. You won’t be disappointed!

What will the $8500 target of funding go towards?

We’ll be using your generous support to create a full website, to document and create content around our project and the community support we’re generating, and to cover operating costs to run the tours in February including insurance, tour guide and other costs.

What will happen if you don’t reach $8,500?

Firstly, we’ll cry! Only joking! The majority of our target ($8,500) is to enable us to create the most amazing website we have our heart set on. With less money we can still fulfil our project aims. Just the scale and scope of our web platform will be a little more modest. We’ve bootstrapped everything to date, so we’ve proven it can be done!

How does South of the Border aim to support grassroots community initiatives?

South of the Border supports grassroots community initiatives in and around Redfern in three ways. Firstly, we provide technical assistance for a whole manner of tasks such as developing social media and expanding networks. Secondly, we give these initiatives a platform to connect with a wider scope of people. Lastly, we directly fund some initiatives that we interact with during our Redfern walking experience.

Is there opportunity for me to become involved in South of the Border and the work they do?

We’re always looking for passionate people to collaborate with us! Start a conversation by emailing us at contact@gosouth.co .

story:
Dear Friends,

Meet my friend Paul.  I met Paul Kamara in November 2008 while working with my professor on a public health project in Sierra Leone.  During that time Paul was our driver.  He coordinated our safety via cell phone and delivered us to various locations like the Ministry of Health.  In the evenings, he coordinated with the guard and delivered us safely back to our apartment.  During that time, we talked a lot about the differences between growing up in the USA and in Sierra Leone.  

Although we are similar age, Paul has survived a 10-year civil war.  He is also the sole breadwinner in his family.  He supports his parents and his sisters by providing housing, food, clothing, and school fees.  In addition, he also helps his extended family.  Finding work is Sierra Leone is very difficult.  Anyone who is employed shares everything they have with their families.  This has meant, that despite having a job, Paul has had to forgo higher education for himself and because he is supporting his whole family he isn’t able to save or invest in his own future.

Paul is outgoing and hardworking.  He is very smart, and has an interest in accounting.  He is also a devout Christian.  The amazing thing about Paul is that — despite hardship — he is positive, resourceful and a go-getter.  Paul’s dream is to own his own business.  This would grant him the opportunity to further help his family and community.  
 
During the past 4 years we have been working together for Paul to start his own commercial transport service in the capital city of Freetown, a greater  opportunity for prosperity than his current driving job.  Together with an American friend and consultant who lives and works in Sierra Leone, Paul has created an itemized business plan, complete with profit analysis.  I’ve offered my own time and money for this project because I know what it is like to have a dream, and because I believe in Paul 100%.  By helping Paul start a viable and profitable business, this means helping his entire immediate and extended family, and his community. 
 
Sierra Leone has suffered greatly, not only from one of the most violent and traumatic civil wars in history, but also from extreme poverty, weak public systems and rampant disease and illness.  The country needs smart, young and successful entrepreneurs like Paul to start pushing the country forward in growth and progress.  I ask you to please play a part in Paul’s success by making a donation.

Thank you!


Kate Hayden
 

What We Need and What You Get

The goal is to raise $6,000 US dollars.  Please review Paul's Projected Profit Analysis in the "Images" section here.  The currency is in Sierra Leonean Leones and US dollars.  There you can see his projected start-up costs, expenses, and income.

This may be the most important donation of your lifetime.  Please help change the life of a whole family in Africa.  Whether you are an entrepreneur, philanthropist, or just a kind person, please contribute.  We are also offering "perks" to sweeten the deal for you (see below).

If we don't meet our goal Paul can use this money to start a smaller business as a street vendor or we may continue to fundraise through other channels.  If we exceed our goal, and raise $13,000, Paul can purchase an 18 seater mini bus.  This will increase his transport capacity and also his profits.

Other Ways You Can Help

Please share this campaign with others.  Every donation big or small helps.  Please share this link on Twitter, Facebook, and email.  Tell your friends and family!  Thank you.
story_txt:
Dear Friends,

Meet my friend Paul.  I met Paul Kamara in November 2008 while working with my professor on a public health project in Sierra Leone.  During that time Paul was our driver.  He coordinated our safety via cell phone and delivered us to various locations like the Ministry of Health.  In the evenings, he coordinated with the guard and delivered us safely back to our apartment.  During that time, we talked a lot about the differences between growing up in the USA and in Sierra Leone.  


Although we are similar age, Paul has survived a 10-year civil war.  He is also the sole breadwinner in his family.  He supports his parents and his sisters by providing housing, food, clothing, and school fees.  In addition, he also helps his extended family.  Finding work is Sierra Leone is very difficult.  Anyone who is employed shares everything they have with their families.  This has meant, that despite having a job, Paul has had to forgo higher education for himself and because he is supporting his whole family he isn’t able to save or invest in his own future. 


Paul is outgoing and hardworking.  He is very smart, and has an interest in accounting.  He is also a devout Christian.  The amazing thing about Paul is that — despite hardship — he is positive, resourceful and a go-getter.  Paul’s dream is to own his own business.  This would grant him the opportunity to further help his family and community.  

 
During the past 4 years we have been working together for Paul to start his own commercial transport service in the capital city of Freetown, a greater  opportunity for prosperity than his current driving job.  Together with an American friend and consultant who lives and works in Sierra Leone, Paul has created an itemized business plan, complete with profit analysis.  I’ve offered my own time and money for this project because I know what it is like to have a dream, and because I believe in Paul 100%.  By helping Paul start a viable and profitable business, this means helping his entire immediate and extended family, and his community. 
 
Sierra Leone has suffered greatly, not only from one of the most violent and traumatic civil wars in history, but also from extreme poverty, weak public systems and rampant disease and illness.  The country needs smart, young and successful entrepreneurs like Paul to start pushing the country forward in growth and progress.  I ask you to please play a part in Paul’s success by making a donation. 
Thank you!

Kate Hayden

 


What We Need and What You Get
The goal is to raise $6,000 US dollars.  Please review Paul's Projected Profit Analysis in the "Images" section here.  The currency is in Sierra Leonean Leones and US dollars.  There you can see his projected start-up costs, expenses, and income.
This may be the most important donation of your lifetime.  Please help change the life of a whole family in Africa.  Whether you are an entrepreneur, philanthropist, or just a kind person, please contribute.  We are also offering "perks" to sweeten the deal for you (see below).
If we don't meet our goal Paul can use this money to start a smaller business as a street vendor or we may continue to fundraise through other channels.  If we exceed our goal, and raise $13,000, Paul can purchase an 18 seater mini bus.  This will increase his transport capacity and also his profits.


Other Ways You Can Help
Please share this campaign with others.  Every donation big or small helps.  Please share this link on Twitter, Facebook, and email.  Tell your friends and family!  Thank you.

story:
My hometown needs help! 

Veterns, History buffs, people that care about our American heritage! WE NEED YOUR HELP! October 12th Vandals tore up our beautiful, historical cemetery. This is a CRIME! This cemetery has stood here since 1828 and is the final resting place for many of our military personnel and people that helped make America what it is today! Kendall is a part of the Erie Canal, the underground railroad, Civil war history, the Dutch pioneers history, etc.etc. This cemetery holds the past in it hands and now it needs our help to heal the terrible wounds some vandals caused. ~ WE CAN'T DO IT ALONE ~

Kendall is a very small community of farmers and many retirees. We are rich in heritage but not in money. Beechwood Cemetary is very important to us. 

We don't have an actual figure of how much it will cost to clean up and restore what we can to the cemetary. I just learned that through other sources we are able to get the stone work done on the headstones and monuments for around $3000! Many people in the town would like to see our little chapel converted to a  memorial for the service people that served our country from Kendall. That will be costly because of the vandalizm and condition it's in. 

 

LET'S GIVE OUR HEROS A FITTING MEMORIAL IN THIS BEAUTIUFL LITTLE CHAPEL! THEY DESERVE IT! 

Thank you to all the contributors!

story:
*************************En français plus bas.*******************************

We, Max Godber, Mauricio Buschinelli, Iman Khailat and Sam Richer, are the co-founders of Cycle AlimenTerre. We are 4 roommates that live in a Do-it-yourself (DIY) household. We came together to develop an urban agriculture model that could benefit communities directly. We wanted to see an affordable and healthy produce alternative to box stores or expensive markets emerge in our neighborhood. We set out to farm local, naturally grown vegetables in people’s unused backyards and distribute them by bicycle market.

After 2014's pilot project, we are in it for another year and could use your help with our start-up costs. We believe our business model is sustainable and that by the end of the 4th year, our operations will pay for themselves. We just need a boost to get off the ground!

How does this help?

  • Improve food security in our neighborhood by increasing access to fresh, natural produce.
  • Low production costs du to community involvement and the lack of expensive machinery allow us to sell our quality produce cheaper.
  • Increase overall well-being and good health for the residents of my neighborhood. 
  • Positively impact our environment by promoting active transport and chemical-free agriculture,
  • Increase green spaces.
  • Offer learning opportunities for volunteers and interns.

How does it work?

We install micro-farms in backyards donated to the project by community members. We use the SPIN farming (Small-Plot-INtensive) method to maximise our yield and reduce our costs.


Here are SPIN-Farming's Key Characteristics*:

  • Production based
  • Sub-acre in scale
  • Low capital intensive
  • Entrepreneurially driven
  • Environmentally friendly
  • Close to markets

We maintain the gardens with the help of volunteers and interns. A portion of the harvested produce is divided between the land donors and the rest is brought to market. In our neighborhood, four areas have been classified as food deserts: «spaces of relative exclusion where people suffer from psysical and economical barriers to access healthy food**». These food deserts is where we wish to concentrate our efforts. 

All our work is done using bikes. We transport compost, tools, seedlings, wood and much more, all using bike trailers. This keeps our operations eco-friendly and cost effective.

In order to finance our project, CAT will also be producing micro-greens using an indoor growing set-up. This will allow us to produce a delicious, healthy, fresh baby green 10 months out of the year. They will then be sold to local merchants and restaurants.

**Cummins, Steven et Sally Macintyre (2002).  «Food  deserts » : Evidence and assumption  in health policy. British Medical Journal  BMJ,  Vol. 325,  p 436:439. 

*SPINFarming. 7th of March 2015. SPIN – A New Way to Learn to Farm. Accessed: 7th March 2015 <http://spinfarming.com/whatsSpin/>

Can we do it?

We aren't going to lie to you, farming can be risky business. The growing season is unpredictable, every year brings new climactic challenges and different waves of pests. 

However, we already have one year of operation. The 2015 growing season will only be better. We are better prepared, better organised, more knowledgeable...

But more important, now we have help.

  • We now have the support of over half a dozen influencial organisations within our neighborhood.
  • We have volunteers and interns working with us, giving invaluable support and help.
  • We have more land, in better locations.
  • We have allies providing us with growing space, equipment, discounts, advice.
  • We have very experienced farmers and gardeners lending their brains.

We have everything we need this year to really kick butt!

YES WE CAN!

Our biggest setback is our total lack of funds. So far, we've been financing CAT through the sale of 2014's produce and our own meager salaries. Unfortunately, we won't survive another season without some help with our start-up costs.

And that's where you come in!! 

The money you donate to our project will go into:

Branding and Marketing
Business Administration
Equipment
Growing space
Hand Tools
Irrigation
Office Supplies
Organic Materials
Paying coordinators
Row Cover System
Seedling; Microgreen Propagator
Trailer Systems
Trellis System

Please help us develop this model in our neighborhood and fill a need that is currently being unmet. Check out our cool artesanal gifts you can receive when you back our project.

As an incubator project of the NDG Food Depot, you can receive a tax receipt for donations over 20$ should you wish so. Please note that you can not be issued a tax receipt if you claim a perk. Please send an email to lecyclealimenterre@gmail.com to claim your tax receipt.

Thanks for your time. We know you're busy, so we kept it short. Should you want to know more, we'll gladly answer any questions. Please visit our FB page www.facebook.com/cyclealimenterre or send us an e-mail at lecyclealimenterre@gmail.com


Sincerely,

The team @ CAT

*****************************************************************************

          *****************************Français*****************************

Nous sommes Max Godber, Mauricio Buschinelli, Iman Khailat et Samantha Richer, colocs et co-fondateurEs de Cycle AlimenTerre. Nous nous sommes unis en 2014 pour développer un modèle en agriculture urbaine qui bénéficierait notre communauté. Notre désir: voir l’émergence de marchés locaux qui fourniraient des produits sains et abordables comme alternative aux supermarchés. Nous nous sommes mis a l'épreuve en tentant de cultiver des légumes dans les cours arrières inutilisées pour ensuite faire la distribution de ceux-ci au moyen d'un marché à vélo.

Suite à l'année pilote de 2014, nous nous lançons de nouveau pour la saison 2015, mais nous avons besoin d'un petit coup de main. Nous avons confiance que notre modèle d'affaire est durable et nos projections démontrent que nous devrions être rentable à partir de notre 4e année d'opérations. D'ici là, nous aurons besoin d'aide avec les coûts de départ.

Mais en quoi ce projet est-il bénéfique?


  • Amélioration de la sécurité alimentaire dans notre quartier en augmentant la disponibilité et l'accessibilité de produits frais.
  • L'implication volontaire ainsi que l'absence de machinerie lourde permet de réduire nos coûts d'opération et de vendre nos légumes à un meilleur prix.
  • Amélioration générale du bien-être de notre communauté à travers de saines habitudes de vie et une bonne alimentation.
  • Impact positif sur l’environnement en promouvant le transport actif et une agriculture sans produits chimiques.
  • Augmentation des espaces verts.
  • Opportunités d'appentissage pour bénévoles et stagiaires.

    Comment ça fonctionne?

    Nous installons des mini-fermes dans les cours arrières qui nous sont offertes par des membres de notre communauté. Nous utilisons la méthode «SPIN farming»(Small-Plot INtensive) pour cultiver nos légumes.

    Voici les caractéristiques de la methode SPIN farming*

    • Basé sur la production
    • Moins d'un acre
    • Investissement initial minime
    • Bon pour de jeunes entrepreneurs
    • Écologique
    • Près des marchés
    Nous entretenons les jardins avec l'aide de bénévoles et de stagiaires. Une portion des récoltes est offerte aux propriétaires des terrains cultivés et l'autre portion est vendue dans les marchés. Ḑans notre quartier, il y a 4 régions classifiées comme désert alimentaire, c'est-à-dire: «espaces de relative exclusion où les gens souffrent des barrières physiques et économiques pour accéder à une nourriture saine**». C'est dans ces régions que nous désirons concentrer nos efforts

    Tout le travail est complété à l'aide de vélos. Nous transportons notre compost, nos outils, nos semences, et encore plus avec notre remorque pour bicyclettes. Grâce à cela, notre projet est éco-responsable et rentable.

    Afin de financer le projet, CycleAlimenTerre cultivera aussi des pousses à l'intérieur pour 10 mois de l'année. Ces pousses seront par la suite vendues aux commercants et restaurants locaux.

    **Cummins, Steven et Sally Macintyre (2002).  «Food  deserts » : Evidence and assumption  in health policy. British Medical Journal  BMJ,  Vol. 325,  p 436:439. 

    *SPINFarming. 7th of March 2015. SPIN – A New Way to Learn to Farm. Accessed: 7th March 2015 <http://spinfarming.com/whatsSpin/>

    Mais est-ce possible?

    On ne vous le cachera pas, l'agriculture n'est pas sans risques. Nos cultures seront toujours à la merci du climat et des insectes. Un projet comme celui-ci n'est jamais sans imprévus.

    Cependant, nous croyons fermement que nos activités en 2015 seront nettement meilleures grâce à l'expérience acquise lors de notre année pilote. Nous sommes mieux informés, mieux organisés et bien préparés. 

    Plus encore, cette année nous aurons beaucoup d'aide!

    • Nous avons le support de près d'une dizaine d'organismes dans notre communauté.
    • Nous avons maintenant une grande équipe de bénévoles et stagiaires.
    • Nous avons des meilleurs terrains qui sont aussi mieux situés.
    • Nous avons des alliéEs qui nous fournirons en équipement et offrirons des rabais et de précieux conseils.
    • Nous avons la collaboration de plusieurs agriculteurs saisonnés pour répondre à toutes nos questions.


    Cette année, la réussite est à notre portée!

    Nous réussirons!

    Notre plus grand obstacle à ce jour est sans aucun doute le manque de fonds. Jusqu'à présent, CycleAlimenTerre s'est financé entièrement avec les ventes de 2014 et avec le peu d'argent de nos poches.

    Malheureusement, cette année, cela ne suffira pas.

    Nous ne pourrons pas continuer le projet SANS VOTRE AIDE!

    Voici où iront vos sous:

    Administration
    Logo et Marketing
    Équipement
    Espace de culture des semis
    Filets protecteurs
    Irrigation
    Outils
    Matériel de bureau
    Matière organique
    Salaires des coordonateurs
    Remorque à vélo
    Semis; Propagateur de pousses
    Treillis

    SVP aidez-nous à développer notre modèle dans notre quartier et à répondre à un besoin important. Nous offrons de petits cadeaux artisanaux en échange de votre don.

    Étant donné que nous sommes un projet incubé par le dépot alimentaire NDG, vous pouvez recevoir un reçu d'impôt pour les dons de 20$ ou plus. Veuillez noter que vous ne recevrez pas de reçu d'impôt si vous selectionez un cadeau. Si vous désirez recevoir un reçu d'impôt, envoyez votre demande à lecyclealimenterre@gmail.com

    Merci de votre collaboration. Nous savons que vous êtes bien occupés, donc nous avons gardé le tout concis. Nous répondons volontiers à toute question à l'égard du projet. Vous pouvez nous écrire à lecyclealimenterre@gmail.com ou visitez notre page FB www.facebook.com/cyclealimenterre . 

    Sincèrement,

    L'équipe de Cycle AlimenTerre

story:
Born of friendship and a love of good spirits, Mystic Bourbon Liqueur is a fast-growing handmade bourbon based drink from Durham, North Carolina.  Founded in 2013, we've built Mystic from a dream to reality, growing throughout the Carolinas, Virginia and into Washington D.C..  Mystic has made it's way onto shelves in hundreds of stores, and we've sold tens of thousands of bottles in the process.


We still make Mystic one bottle at a time, with a smooth and complex flavor that comes from top quality ingredients and our passion to make an exceptional product.  We open between three and five barrels of our fine bourbon each time we begin to make a batch of Mystic.

Along the way we've noticed that the barrels of our base bourbon we've aged in Durham, North Carolina develop more complex flavors and aromas.  Every so often we find a truly exceptional barrel that we reserve for a special release.  We call this bourbon the "Heart of Mystic" and we want to bring it to the world as a single-barrel expression, bottled at barrel strength, sold exclusively through this crowdfunding event.  
We've also decided to build our own barrel house to age all of our whiskey in North Carolina, and we need your help to do it.

What We Need & What You Get

We are raising a minimum of $15,000 to set up a barrel house to begin aging all of our barreled bourbon in North Carolina, along with a tasting room and event space.  This will be a place for us to offer tours, educate our fans about bourbon, and continue handmade, small-batch production of Mystic as we grow.


In exchange for your support, we are offering you exclusive access to our two best barrels of Mystic's base bourbon.  The Heart of Mystic is an exceptional 45% wheat, straight bourbon whiskey.  We will draw it from the barrels, non-chill filter it, and bottle it by hand at barrel strength (usually about 117 proof).
We're also offering a class on bourbon called Bourbon 101.   Learn everything you always wanted to know about America's whiskey in a fun tasting and hands-on class.  
We are also offering signed and numbered bottles of Mystic Bourbon Liqueur from the last run under the classic label, and the first run under our new label.  There are also a small number of bottles of our "Founders' Honey" release, featuring honey from our own hives.



You can also get tasting glasses and t-shirts featuring our new logo.

For those willing to dig a little deeper, we are also offering unique bottling experiences that will bring you closer to Mystic than ever before.  For those with a taste for adventure and a bigger budget, we're ready to hit the road with you and explore the roots of Bourbon together.

Thanks for taking the time to learn more about Mystic and the friendships behind the brand.  Please know that we feel an incredible sense of pride and accomplishment every time someone buys a bottle of Mystic and enjoys it.  Please share Mystic, and our campaign with your friends and family. 

We can't wait to meet you in-person at one of our tasting events, and during tours of the new barrel house!

PLEASE NOTE:  If you live in North Carolina (due to state prohibition of spirits sales), you'll get exclusive access to these spirits at your North Carolina ABC store.  For single bottles, we will be able to sell them to you from the door of the distillery. For those living out-of-state, we will have them shipped to you directly from a D.C. area spirits retailer, and shipping in the Continental U.S. is already included.
story_txt:
Born of friendship and a love of good spirits, Mystic Bourbon Liqueur is a fast-growing handmade bourbon based drink from Durham, North Carolina.  Founded in 2013, we've built Mystic from a dream to reality, growing throughout the Carolinas, Virginia and into Washington D.C..  Mystic has made it's way onto shelves in hundreds of stores, and we've sold tens of thousands of bottles in the process.




We still make Mystic one bottle at a time, with a smooth and 
complex flavor that comes from top quality ingredients and our passion 
to make an exceptional product.  We open between three and five barrels of our fine bourbon each time we begin to make a batch of Mystic.

Along the way we've noticed that the barrels of our base bourbon we've aged in Durham, North Carolina develop more complex flavors and aromas.  Every so often we find a truly exceptional barrel that we reserve for a special release.  We call this bourbon the "Heart of Mystic" and we want to bring it to the world as a single-barrel expression, bottled at barrel strength, sold exclusively through this crowdfunding event.  We've also decided to build our own barrel house to age all of our whiskey in North Carolina, and we need your help to do it.

We are raising a minimum of $15,000 to set up a barrel house to begin aging all of our barreled bourbon in North Carolina, along with a tasting room and event space.  This will be a place for us to offer tours, educate our fans about bourbon, and continue handmade, small-batch production of Mystic as we grow.

You can also get tasting glasses and t-shirts featuring our new logo.
For those willing to dig a little deeper, we are also offering unique bottling experiences that will bring you closer to Mystic than ever before.  For those with a taste for adventure and a bigger budget, we're ready to hit the road with you and explore the roots of Bourbon together.

story:
A big thank you to our contributors! We didn't make our goal but that doesn't mean that we're out of the race. We will continue to use different outlets to raise funds.

Other Ways You Can Help after the Indiegogo campaign
  • Buy a coworking t-shirt here
  • "Like" our Facebook page
  • "Follow" us on Twitter
  • Do you live in the West Bloomfield, Michigan area? Support our small business and have your next meeting at Visionary Meetings after it opens. We will provide conference rooms, private offices, shared office space. We need a list of people who are willing and able to use this office space for our bank loan process. Please fill out this form so we can contact you when we ready to have you as a guest.
  • The owner, Angela Samuels, is an book marketing specialist. She provides phone consulting concerning book marketing on her website. If you know anyone that is in need of her services please contact her.
  • We also have created a wish list on our website if anyone would like to donate items.
Thank You!



Top Five Reasons to Love Visionary Meetings

1.  Visionary Meetings is place where I can network with other entrepreneurs and professionals.

2.  Visionary Meetings is a place where I can get a couple hours of work done while my child is being taken care of and taught with hands on learning activities.

3.  Visionary Meetings is a place where I can get out of the house to work for a couple of days out of the week and meet new people.

4.  Visionary Meetings is a place where I can rent a conference room for my meetings.

5.  Visionary Meetings is a place where I can focus on my work because of distractions at home.


This location will provide a professional work and meeting environment for the parents while having an affordable daycare for their children onsite.

Visionary Meetings will provide:

  • Conference Rooms
  • Meetings Rooms
  • Coworking Space
  • Resident Coworking Space (24/7 access)
  • Private Offices (24/7 access)
  • Onsite daycare services during staffed hours
  • Mail Services
  • Business Workshops

Location - West Bloomfield

The proposed coworking space will be near West Bloomfield, MI. The population for West Bloomfield is around 64,000 people. It's located in Oakland County, Michigan.

  • West Bloomfield was named No. 37 on Money magazine's Top 100 Small Cities in 2012 (Wikipedia).
  • West Bloomfield is also #6 on the list of 100 highest-income places with a population of at least 50,000 people.

Our Team

  • Angela Samuels - Owner and founder
  • Poly A. Endrasik Jr - Communications
  • Angel Kwiatkowski - Mentor and owner of Cohere coworking
  • Terry Beltran - Special Events Coordinator


We are raising money online from Now until March 31, 2014 to help with startup costs.

The money raised will go towards Wi-Fi, office and daycare furniture and other equipment to run an efficient office.

Many women struggle trying to have a career and a family too. With technology being what it is today, many mothers are choosing to work from home or telecommuting. However, they still need uninterrupted time to get the job done.  Daycare can often be expensive and many families spend thousands on day care every year. This can make many families suffer financially. 

Visionary Meetings vows to help other women start or grow their company and by reducing the barriers that is needed for them to succeed.

We’re creating Visionary Meetings on the behalf of millions of women who spend countless hours taking care of their families and still devote time to working and creating that dream business like myself.

I’m one of those women that try to balance work and family. I know firsthand how hard it is to rearrange your finances so you can have enough to pay daycare cost and maybe a couple other bills.

Due to the economy it has been a challenge obtaining capital to fund our project.  The current campaign will only fund 1/3 of the necessary capital required to open the doors. We are in the process of seeking a small loan for the rest of the amount needed.

Perks

Please note that perks that require an items that needs to ship may be shipped in separate packages.

We will add a NEW perk every week so come and visit us every week. Unpopular or unclaimed perks may be removed so if you see a perk you like make sure you claim it right away. If you’re interested in discounts for prepaid coworking space, we have two listed. please contact us as we will be adding more prepaid weeks in the coming weeks after the initial launch as details on of construction start to come in. Visionary Meetings will offer conference rooms, onsite daycare, limited number of private offices and a open coworking space.

T-shirt with Visionary Meetings Logo - $25

Pledge levels will be set up with specific rewards for donations to the project. Any amount will help and no pledge will go unrewarded.

Visionary Interview Perk

This perk includes Thank You perk + and a 45 minutes online interview by the founder of Visionary Meetings, Angela Samuels. Hear an interview that she did with Melanie Jacob, nutritionist HERE.



Company Information

Green Phoenix Mart

PO Box 62 Keego Harbor, MI 48320

Visit our Frequently Asked Questions Page

You can give by sending pledges to the address above and we will make a pledge in your name and send you a special thank you gift for your donation.

Sincerely,

Angela Samuels
Founder and Owner of Visionary Meetings

P.S. Don't forget to post some words of wisdom for us about coworking or business in general in the comment area. Plus I'll be giving free shout outs to the top 2 people who are getting the most referrals on Indiegogo each week on the comments page.

Please Pledge TODAY!
Questions can be directed to our contact form.

Special Thanks to:

Burke Video Company - Troy, Michigan

Mentor Angel Kwiatkowski - Owner of Cohere Coworking


Get a chance to win a $50 Amazon gift card by sharing this campaign (with your Indiegogo unique code).
Contest ends Monday, March 31, 2014 at midnight. Winner will be chosen on April 3, 2014.

See Indiegogo Contest Details for more information.

Thank You for Visiting Our Fundraising Page

story:
My name is Daniel Roberts and I live with Spina Bifida, I am 19 years old. My racing career started in August of 2009 at the age of 14 in Snowflake, Arizona which was my first race ever. Since that day I have dreamed of becoming an ATV Racing Professional. My life revolves around my racing, as well as school, and volunteer work. At school I keep a 3.2 GPA. I was able to attend Arcadia High School in the morning for a couple of classes everyday and then be home schooled the rest of the day because of my condition. Even though I am classified with Spina Bifida at an S1 L6 level on the spine, I have never had to have a shunt or go through the tremendously awful and heart wrenching surgery...I was one of the fortunate ones that did not have to endure that. Each level of Spina Bifida is different with all varying degrees based on the opening you are born with on your spine. I have two ports in my stomach and my level affects my lower extremities of my body.

I will always need to be within a short distance of shower facilities because just changing my undergarments is most always not enough. This makes me self conscience as I cannot always get clean without showering, and I have to change several times a day and shower usually 3 times a day or more. But I have learned to be relatively quick about it and it is also quicker and helps because I am  a young man. I was also born with clubbed feet and had to have tendon release surgery done on both feet. They are more like levers now because of the surgery and my lower legs below the knees are not defined with normal calf muscles and are very thin. My racing boots help me to align my feet and protect my lower legs. Even though I live with these things, I consider myself to be very lucky everyday.

Racing is my dream and I take it very seriously, I train very hard and maintain a healthy lifestyle. When I am on the race track I am focused and confident and my results have shown this. Although I have a medical condition I do not let it affect my outlook on life and my racing, in fact it is just the opposite. I choose to use my condition to fuel my determination of racing professionally, to be a positive role model, and to be a beacon of hope to others that live with my level of Spina Bifida.

Any and all help that I receive here will help me to take some of the financial burden from my parents as I also had major shoulder surgery, (bony bankart), which required a few months of rehab this year and I havent be able to race until 3 months ago again. Now I am full steam ahead. Contributions I receive upon completion of this campaign will go towards my racing expenses such as: Gas, Food, Lodging, Entry Fees and Bike Repairs as many of the races are out of state in Northern California, Utah, Nevada and Northern Arizona. If I do not reach my campaign goal, your contributions will go towards my training and my continued future racing events.

My goals are to race all of the WORCS series, most QUAD X races, Many Big 6 races and many local races where I live. I am moving up to the A class in the WORCS series and my goal for that class is to be top 3 in points. I will also be doing the Pro-am class and my goal for that is to be top 5 in points. My focus is to represent promoters, contributors, and myself in a professional manor by my accomplishments. I am also active in volunteer work for those with medical conditions and disabilities in my spare time at the Disability Empowerment Center in Phoenix, AZ. I will be attending college to attain a degree in Occupational Therapy to help others in the future. I appreciate you taking your time to visit and read my dreams and for your consideration to help me achieve them. I want to help others know that Spina Bifida does not have to limit their dreams and aspirations in any way.

Below are some of my recent accomplishments:

Race Accomplishments in 2013

WORCS Series

2nd place in Open B

2nd place in Spt. 15-29 B

Racing Classes for 2014

WORCS

    Production A

    Pro-am

Best In The Desert

    Expert Class

BIG 6

    Expert Class

QUAD X

    450 Intermediate Class

Arizona Grand Prix Series (AZGP)

    450 Pro Class
